ARTICLE 101: CODIFIED ORDINANCES
§ 101.01 DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (A)   All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, articles and sections shall be known and designated as the
“Codified Ordinances of Weirton, West Virginia, 1995” for which designation
“codified ordinances” may be substituted. Code, title, article and section
headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the codified
ordinances.
   (B)   All references to codes, titles, articles and sections are to such
components of the codified ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the “traffic code.”
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation “§” followed by the
number, such as “§ 101.01.”
('71 Code, § 101.01)
Statutory reference:
   Adoption of codified ordinances, see W. V. Code § 8-11-4(b)
§ 101.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this code, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COUNCIL. The legislative authority of the municipality.
   COUNTY. Brooke or Hancock County as applicable to the portion of the city
located therein.
   LAND or LANDS and REAL ESTATE or REAL PROPERTY. Lands, tenements and
heredita-ments, and all rights thereto and interests therein except chattel
interests.
   LAWS OF THE STATE. The Constitution of the State and the Constitution of the
United States, and treaties and laws made in pursuance thereof.
   MUNICIPALITY or CITY. The City of Weirton, West Virginia.
   OFFENSE. Every act or omission for which a fine, forfeiture or punishment is
imposed by law.
   OWNER. When applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner or
tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   PERSON or WHOEVER. Corporations, societies, associations and partnerships.
   PERSONAL ESTATE. or PERSONAL PROPERTY. Goods, chattels, real and personal,
money, credits, investments and the evidences thereof.
   PRECEDING, SUCCEEDING or FOLLOWING. Used in reference to any section or
sections of an article means next preceding, next succeeding or next following
that in which such reference is made.
   PREMISES. As applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   PROPERTY or ESTATE. Both real and personal estate.
   PUBLIC PLACE. Any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school yard, body of
water or watercourse, public conveyance or any other place for the sale of
merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   REGISTERED MAIL. This term includes certified mail.
   STATE. The State of West Virginia or any department, division, commission,
board, educational or other institution of the state.
   STREET. Alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways, viaducts and
all other public thoroughfares within the municipality.
   TENANT or OCCUPANT. As applied to premises, includes any person holding a
written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such
premises alone or with others.
   WRITTEN or IN WRITING. Any representation of words, letters or figures,
whether by printing, engraving, writing or otherwise. But when the signature of
any person is required, it must be in his own proper handwriting, or his mark,
attested, proved or acknowledged.
('71 Code, § 101.02)
Statutory reference:
   For similar definitions, see W. V. Code § 2-2-10
§ 101.03 RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar
and appropriate meaning.
   (B)   Gender and plural. A word importing the singular number only may be
applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; a word
importing the plural number only may be applied to one person or thing as well
as to several; and a word importing the masculine gender only may be applied to
females as well as males.
   (C)   Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall
be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, or if the last
be Sunday, it shall also be excluded.
   (D)   Joint authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three
or more persons confer such authority upon a majority of them, and not upon any
less number.
   (E)   Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law which
shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when the
subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
('71 Code, § 101.03)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code §§ 2-2-3 and 2-2-10
§ 101.04 REPEAL OF REPEALING ACT; EFFECT OF REPEAL.
   (A)   When a law which has repealed another is itself repealed, the former
law shall not be revived without express words for the purpose.
   (B)   The repeal of a law, or its expiration by virtue of any provision
contained therein, shall not affect any offense committed, or penalty or
punishment incurred, before the repeal took effect, or the law expired, save
only that the proceedings thereafter had shall conform as far as practicable to
the laws in force at the time such proceedings take place, unless otherwise
specially provided; and that if any penalty or punishment be mitigated by the
new law, such new law may, with the consent of the party affected thereby, be
applied to any judgment pronounced after it has taken effect.
   (C)   The repeal by any provision of the codified ordinances of an ordinance
validating previous acts, contracts or transactions shall not affect the
validity of such acts, contracts or transactions, but the same shall remain as
valid as if there had been no such repeal, but no further.
('71 Code, § 101.04)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code §§ 2-2-8, 2-2-9 and 2-2-11
§ 101.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (A)   When reference is made to any section or group of sections of the
codified ordinances, such reference shall extend to and include any amendment
of or supplement to the section or group of sections so referred to or any
section or sections hereafter enacted in lieu thereof; and unless otherwise
provided, whenever a reference to a section or group of sections is made in any
amendment or supplement to any section of the codified ordinances hereafter
enacted, such reference shall be deemed to refer to the section or sections as
the same shall then stand or as thereafter amended.
   (B)   Whenever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
section or an inclusive group of sections, such reference shall be construed to
mean a violation of any provision of the section or sections included in such
reference.
   (C)   References in the codified ordinances to action taken or authorized
under designated sections of the codified ordinances include, in every case,
action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the codified ordinances.
('71 Code, § 101.05)
§ 101.06 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   If the provisions of different codes, articles or sections of the codified
ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the
latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same
passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the
meaning or legal effect of the questions of the subject matter taken as a
whole.
('71 Code, § 101.06)
§ 101.07 SEPARABILITY.
   Each section of the codified ordinances and every part of each section is an
independent section and part of a section, and the holding of any section or a
part thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause does not
affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof.
('71 Code, § 101.07)
§ 101.08 SECTION HISTORIES; STATUTORY REFERENCES.
   (A)   As histories for the code sections, the specific number and passage
date of the original ordinance, and the most recent three amending ordinances,
if any, are listed following the text of the code section. Example: (Ord. 10,
passed 5-13-60; Am. Ord. 15, passed 1-1-70; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-1-80; Am.
Ord. 25, passed 1-1-85)
   (B)   (1)   If a statutory cite is included in the history, this indicates
that the text of the section reads substantially the same as the statute.
Example: (W. V. Code § 8-2-9) (Ord. 10, passed 1-17-80; Am. Ord. 20, passed 1-
1-85).
      (2)   If a statutory cite is set forth as a “statutory reference”
following the text of the section, this indicates that the reader should refer
to that statute for further information.
Example:
   § 159.01 PUBLIC RECORDS AVAILABLE.
      This municipality shall make available to any person for inspection or
copying all public records, unless otherwise exempted by state law.
   Statutory reference:
      For provisions concerning the inspection of public records, see W. V.
Code §§ 29B-1-1 through 29B-1-7
§ 101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   (A)   Whenever, in the codified ordinances or in any ordinance of the
municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any
act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise
provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be fined not less than $100
and not more than $500 or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both; provided,
however, such penalty shall not exceed the maximum penalty provided by state
law for the commission of a misdemeanor which is the same or similar to the act
proscribed by the city. The municipality has a right to access fines not less
than $100 per offense and add $10 a day assessment not to exceed the maximum
penalty of $500 per citation. If an excessive penalty should be imposed, then
such excessive penalty shall automatically be reduced to the maximum penalty
which could legally be imposed and the judgment shall be construed as
originally being only in such reduced amount.
   (B)   All ordinances related to driving under the influence of alcohol or
intoxicating liquor shall be subject to the same penalties as the penalties
prescribed by the State of West Virginia for the same offenses.
('71 Code, § 101.99) (Ord. 902, passed 6-12-89; Am. Ord. 2026, passed 12-11-17)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to impose penalties, see W. V. Code §§ 8-11-1 and 8-12-2(11)
   Maximum penalty permitted, see W. V. Code § 8-11-1
ARTICLE 103: OFFICIAL STANDARDS
§ 103.01 INTENDED DAY FOR LEGAL ACTION.
   When a proceeding is directed to take place or any act to be done on any
particular day of the month, if that day falls on Sunday, the next day shall be
the one intended, and when any city action is directed by law to commence or
continue on the afternoon of a day which falls on Saturday afternoon or Sunday,
the following Monday shall be the day intended, except as Council shall
hereafter provide. When adjournment is authorized from day to day, an
adjournment from Saturday noon to Monday will be legal.
('71 Code, § 103.01) (Ord. 125, passed 1-11-60)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 2-2-2
§ 103.02 LEGAL HOLIDAYS ; OFFICIAL ACTS AND COURT PROCEEDINGS .
   (A)   The following days are legal holidays:
      (1)   The first day of January is “New Year's Day”;
      (2)   The third Monday of January is “Martin Luther King's Birthday”;
      (3)   The 12th day of February is “Lincoln's Birthday”;
      (4)   The third Monday of February is “Washington's Birthday”;
      (5)   The last Monday in May is “Memorial Day”;
      (6)   The 20th day of June is “West Virginia Day”;
      (7)   The fourth day of July is “Independence Day”;
      (8)   The first Monday of September is “Labor Day”;
      (9)   The second Monday of October is “Columbus Day”;
      (10)   The 11th day of November is “Veterans' Day”;
      (11)   The fourth Thursday of November is “Thanksgiving Day”;
      (12)   The 25th day of December is “Christmas Day”;
      (13)   Any day on which a general, primary, or special election is held
in the city is a holiday throughout the city; and
      (14)   Any day proclaimed or ordered by the governor or the president of
the United States as a day of special observance or thanksgiving, or a day for
the general cessation of business, is a holiday.
   (B)   If a holiday otherwise described in division (A) of this section falls
on a Sunday, then the following Monday is the legal holiday. If a holiday
otherwise described in division (A) of this section falls on a Saturday, then
the preceding Friday is the legal holiday, provided that this division (B)
shall not apply to division (A)(13) of this section.
   (C)   In computing any period of time prescribed by any applicable provision
of this code or any legislative rule or other administrative rule or regulation
promulgated pursuant to the provisions of state law, the day of the act,
events, default, or omission from which the applicable period begins to run is
not included. The last day of the period so computed is included, unless it is
a Saturday, a Sunday, a legal holiday, or a designated day off, in which event
the prescribed period of time runs until the end of the next day that is not a
Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday, or designated day off.
   (D)   If any applicable provision of this code or any legislative rule or
administrative rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of
state law designates a particular date on, before, or after which an act,
event, default, or omission is required or allowed to occur, and if the
particular date designated falls on a Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday, or
designated day off, then the date on which the act, event, default, or omission
is required or allowed to occur is the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday,
legal holiday, or designated day off.
   (E)   With regard to the courts of this state, the computation of periods of
time, the specific dates or days when an act, event, default, or omission is
required or allowed to occur, and the relationship of those time periods and
dates to Saturdays, Sundays, or legal holidays are governed by rules
promulgated by the supreme court of appeals, and local rules established by
circuit courts.
   (F)   The provisions of this section do not increase or diminish the legal
school holidays provided for in W. V. Code § 18A-5-2.
   (G)   In addition to the holidays listed above, the administrative offices
of the city shall be closed at 12:00 noon on the Friday preceding Easter,
commonly known as “Good Friday.”
('71 Code, § 103.02) (Ord. 124, passed 1-11-60)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 2-2-1
ARTICLE 105: WARDS AND BOUNDARIES

('71 Code, § 105.01) (Ord. 243, passed 11-9-70; Am. Ord. 2206, passed 7-10-23)

ARTICLE 107: CITY PROPERTY
§ 107.01 SPECIFICATIONS FOR MARKING VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   All city-owned motor vehicles and mobile equipment shall be plainly
marked with the name “City of Weirton,” together with the department to which
assigned and the number of such motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment.
Such lettering or marking shall be of a conspicuous color and the letters
thereof shall be not less than two inches high and not less than one inch wide
and shall follow a general pattern or type of lettering as designated by the
City Manager.
   (B)   All cruiser cars and other motor vehicles or mobile equipment used by
the Police Department shall also be so marked, except those cars that are
operated by the Detective Bureau and used by that department for detective or
secret work, shall be marked on the inside of the motor vehicle on the
instrument panel or other appropriate place, plainly visible to persons in such
automobile, with lettering similar to that required in division (A) of this
section.
('71 Code, § 107.01)
Statutory reference:
   Sale and disposition of municipal property, see W. V. Code §§ 8-12-17 and 8-
12-18
§ 107.02 NUMBERS ASSIGNED TO VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT.
   The City Manager shall assign a separate number to each motor vehicle and
piece of motor equipment owned by the city.
('71 Code, § 107.02)
§ 107.03 USE OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT GENERALLY.
   (A)   No city-owned motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment shall be
used, except on business of the city.
   (B)   While going to and from work, employees driving city-owned vehicles
will avoid deviation from the normal route taken each day.
   (C)   Only authorized employees of the city or authorized individuals having
official business with the city are permitted to operate or be a passenger in a
city-owned vehicle. Individuals in the custody or care of authorized city
employees shall not constitute a violation of this rule.
   (D)   When a vehicle is damaged due to an employee's negligence or while
being driven outside the scope of employment, the driver may be required to
reimburse the city for such damages.
   (E)   Whenever a city employee is driving a city-owned vehicle, he or she
shall comply with all traffic regulations and laws relating to driving as well
as use all the safety devices that are provided with the vehicle such as seat
belts, etc.
   (F)   Except for emergency conditions, whenever a city-owned vehicle is left
unattended, the city employee shall lock the vehicle.
   (G)   Any citations and fines relating to the use of a city-owned vehicle by
a city employee shall be paid by the assigned driver of said vehicle.
   (H)   All accidents and citations or fines involving city-owned vehicles
shall be reported as soon as practicable by the employee to a department
supervisor whose responsibility it will be to report the accident to the City
Manager by no later than the next working day. All accidents involving city
commercial vehicles shall be reported immediately to a department supervisor
whose responsibility it will be to arrange for a commercial driver's license
(CDL) drug and alcohol testing as required.
   (I)   All employees must possess a valid operator's license or chauffeur's
license before being permitted to drive a city-owned vehicle.
   (J)   City employees assigned a city-owned vehicle, or who have frequent use
of a city-owned vehicle, shall be required to sign a consent form authorizing
the city to obtain the employee's driver's abstract from the Department of
Motor Vehicles.
   (K)   Any city employee whose driver's license is suspended or revoked by
any court of any state or by the Department of Motor Vehicles shall immediately
report such action to their supervisor or the City Manager.
   (L)   No city employee may operate a city-owned vehicle while under license
suspension or revocation of any state. When such suspension or revocation is
lifted, an employee may drive a city-owned vehicle only after a review by the
City Manager.
   (M)   By January 15th of every year, all department heads shall report to
the City Manager the name of every person assigned a city-owned vehicle or who
may have frequent use of a city-owned vehicle and verification that the
employee presented to the department head a valid driver's license, and the
date that the department head verified the same.
   (N)   A city-owned vehicle assigned to an employee shall continue to be part
of the vehicle fleet and is not to be considered as assigned to the employee
personally.
   (O)   If any employee cannot comply with the policies set forth in this
chapter, the employee shall not be assigned nor permitted to drive a city-owned
vehicle.
   (P)   Failure to comply with any part of these rules may result in
disciplinary action up to and including termination, and this may include the
loss of the consent to drive the city-owned vehicle home.
('71 Code, § 107.03) (Ord. 1552, passed 12-10-07) Penalty, see §
101.99
§ 107.04 USE OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT BEYOND CORPORATE LIMITS.
   (A)   No city-owned motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment shall be
taken more than one mile outside the corporate limits of the city, without
permission or order for each particular trip so taken from the head of the
department to which such motor vehicle or piece of mobile equipment is
assigned, except police cars when in fresh pursuit. When such permission is
granted, the procedure hereinafter set out shall be followed.
      (1)   When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the
Police Department, a written record shall be made to the desk sergeant showing
the time of the departure, the destination and the reason for leaving the city.
Upon the return, a report shall immediately be made to such desk sergeant of
the time of such return.
      (2)   When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the Fire
Department, a written record similar in form to that required for the Police
Department shall be made at the office of the Chief of the Fire Department.
      (3)   When the motor vehicle or mobile equipment is assigned to the
Street or Garbage Department, a written record similar in form to that required
for the Police Department shall be made to the clerk at the City Garage.
      (4)   All other persons duly authorized to leave the corporate limits in
city-owned motor vehicles or mobile equipment, who are assigned or work in the
City Hall, shall make the report in the manner and in the form required by the
Police Department to the clerk at the City Engineer's office, if available, and
if not available, the report shall be made to the police desk sergeant, and
upon return, the report shall be made at the same place as the report was made
when leaving.
   (B)   The written records of the departure from the corporate limits of
city-owned motor vehicles and mobile equipment shall be retained in the office
of the head of the department to which such motor vehicle or mobile equipment
is assigned for at least 60 days from the date of return from such trip. The
head of each department shall be responsible for the proper making of such
reports.
('71 Code, § 107.04)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 107.05 ENFORCEMENT.
   The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the City Manager.
('71 Code, § 107.05)
ARTICLE 108: CLEAN INDOOR AIR ACT
§ 108.01 TITLE.
   This article shall be known as the "Weirton Clean Indoor Air Ordinance."
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07)
§ 108.02 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   SMOKING. Inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar,
cigarette, pipe, or other lighted smoking device for burning tobacco or any
other-product.
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07)
§ 108.03 SMOKING PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No smoking shall be permitted in any building or structure owned or
leased by the city, including, but not limited to, the municipal building, Mary
H. Weir Public Library, Millsop Community Center, fire departments, water
treatment plant, sanitary plant and public work's.
   (B)   No smoking shall be permitted in any vehicle owned or leased by the
city.
   (C)   The prohibition stated in division (A) above extends to all areas and
rooms within said building or structure, including, but not limited to,
offices, meeting rooms, hallways, storage areas, garages, restrooms, elevators,
jails or stairways. For purposes of this article, no room or office within any
building or structure owned or leased by the city shall be considered to be
"private" and not subject to the prohibition on smoking.
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07) Penalty, see §
108.99
§ 108.04 ENFORCEMENT OF ARTICLE.
   The provisions of this article shall be strictly enforced and no person,
board, committee or department head is authorized or permitted to override,
amend, modify or change this article in any way in whole or part.
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07)
§ 108.05 SIGN.
   Every building or structure affected by this article shall have posted at
each entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited and
the building or facility is smoke-free. The City Manager shall approve of said
sign and its location.
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07)
§ 108.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and punished as follows:
   (A)   The first infraction shall result in a fine of no less than $5 nor
more than $25.
   (B)   A second violation within a 12-month period shall result in a fine of
no less than $50 nor more than $100.
   (C)   A fine of no less than $100 nor more than $500 shall be levied for
each additional violation of this article within a 12-month period.
   (D)   Any employee of the city who violates this article may be subject to
disciplinary action in lieu of any criminal penalties set forth herein.
   (E)   Non-compliance with the posting of signs stated in §
108.05 above is not a defense or a mitigating factor to any criminal charges or
disciplinary action.
(Ord. 1535, passed 9-10-07)
ARTICLE 109: ELECTIONS
§ 109.01 [RESERVED].
§ 109.02 [RESERVED].
§ 109.03 [RESERVED].
§ 109.04 CANDIDATE FILING FEES.
   (A)   Any candidate who desires to run for Mayor or member of Council in the
city shall file a certificate of announcement for such office and shall pay a
filing fee.
   (B)   Candidate filing fees for the city's elected offices shall be as
follows:
 
Mayor $100.00 Member of Council $ 50.00
 
   (C)   The aforesaid filing fees may be waived upon a candidate's written
request, which request shall be accompanied by that candidate's filing of the
appropriate documentation required by state law for such waiver.
(Ord. 1363, passed 12-30-02)
§ 109.05 WITHDRAWAL OF CANDIDACY.
   (A)   Any candidate for municipal office who wishes to withdraw their
candidacy and to have his or her name removed from the municipal primary
election ballot must file a written statement of such withdrawal from candidacy
in the City Clerk's office by on or before 12:00 noon of the first Friday
immediately following the close of the candidate filing period. Such written
statement of withdrawal from candidacy must be signed by the candidate, dated,
and duly notarized. Upon the timely receipt of any candidate's written notice
of withdrawal as aforesaid, the City Clerk shall remove that candidate's name
from the municipal primary election ballot list. The names of all candidates
who have filed for municipal office and who have not withdrawn their names by
the aforesaid deadline shall appear on the municipal primary election ballot.
Upon the expiration of the aforesaid deadline to withdraw, the City Clerk shall
proceed with the preparation of the municipal primary election ballot for
certification and printing.
   (B)   Any candidate for municipal office who wishes to withdraw their
candidacy and to have his or her name removed from the municipal general
election ballot must file a written statement of such withdrawal from candidacy
in the City Clerk's Office by on or before 12:00 noon of the first Friday
immediately following the certification of the election results from the
municipal primary election; provided, however, that, in the event that a
recount is requested by any candidate and such recount is conducted, the last
day to file such written statement of withdrawal from candidacy in regard to
the municipal general election shall be by on or before 12:00 noon of the first
Friday immediately following the final certification of the municipal primary
election results after such recount. Such written statement of withdrawal from
candidacy must be signed by the candidate, dated, and duly notarized. Upon the
timely receipt of any candidate's written notice of withdrawal as aforesaid,
the City Clerk shall remove that candidate's name from the municipal general
election ballot list. The names of all candidates who have won their respective
municipal primary election nomination for office and who have not withdrawn
their names by the aforesaid deadline shall appear on the municipal general
election ballot. Upon the expiration of the aforesaid deadline to withdraw, the
City Clerk shall proceed with the preparation of the municipal general election
ballot for certification and printing.
(Ord. 1365, passed 12-30-02)

ARTICLE 111. COUNCIL
§ 111.01 COUNCIL MEETINGS WHICH FALL ON HOLIDAYS.
   When the day set for Council meetings, which is the first Monday after the
first Tuesday every month, falls on a holiday for which the City Building is
closed for business, the Council meeting will be held on the following day
(Tuesday).
(Ord. 954, passed 11-13-91)
§ 111.02 COUNCIL TO APPROVE REMOVAL OF HANDICAPPED SPACES WITH ONE READING.
   The city establishes one reading for the removal of handicapped parking
spaces.
(Ord. 1650, passed 8-10-09)
§ 111.03 AUTHORITY TO PLACE RESTRICTIONS ON STREETS AND HIGHWAYS WITHIN CITY
LIMITS.
   The city hereby establishes authority by this section to grant the City
Council the right to change, modify and or impose certain restrictions such as;
but not limited to, traffic flow, stop and other road signs, traffic lights,
speed limits, weight restrictions, closures, that it deems necessary to certain
streets and highways under the state's jurisdiction but within the city limits.
This authority will enable City Council to quickly address issues and concerns
that are a high priority to its citizens and business owners and which they
believe is in the best interest of public safety and welfare. This ordinance
specifically states that the City Council by majority vote or, the Chief of
Police of the City of Weirton, in matters that the Chief of Police would deem
emergent, shall have the authority to change, modify and/or impose certain
restrictions such as but not limited to traffic flow, stop and other road
signs, traffic lights, speed limits, weight restrictions, closures that it
deems necessary to certain streets and highways under the state's jurisdiction
but within the city limits.
(Ord. 1793, passed 9-8-15)
ARTICLE 113: POLITICAL ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED ON CITY-OWNED PROPERTY
§ 113.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY OF WEIRTON. Includes the City of Weirton Parks and Recreation, Weirton
Sanitary Board, Weirton Area Water Board, Weirton Public Works, Weirton Fire
Department and any other agency or sub-agency of the City of Weirton.
   CONTRIBUTIONS. Financial or in-kind contributions.
   POLITICAL ACTIVITY OR CAMPAIGNING. Participating or intervening in, directly
or indirectly, any political campaign, or on behalf of (or in opposition to)
any candidate for public office (including oneself), political party or
political group and includes meetings, conferences, interviews, discussions or
sessions intended to promote the success or failure of any political candidate,
party or group.
(Ord. 1564(A), passed 3-10-08)
§ 113.02 PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (A)   No Mayor, Council Member or city employee shall, directly or
indirectly, engage in the following conduct at the municipal building, on any
city-owned property, in any city-owned vehicle or while wearing a city uniform:
      (1)   Wear any political buttons or stickers of any kind or nature;
      (2)   Engage in any political activity or campaigning;
      (3)   Solicit or seek any assessment or contribution for any political
candidate or committee;
      (4)   Use any official authority or influence for the purpose of
interfering with or affecting the nomination, election or defeat of any
political candidate; or
      (5)   Coerce or command anyone to pay, lend or contribute anything of
value to a political candidate or committee.
   (B)   These provisions do not prohibit the Mayor, Council Members or city
employees from campaigning for or against any county or municipal ordinance or
resolution, or any state, county or local levy, issue, referendum, ballot
initiative, charter amendment or constitutional amendment.
(Ord. 1564(A), passed 3-10-08) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and fined the sum of $100 plus court costs, or jailed for a period
not to exceed 48 hours, or both. In addition, any person violating the
provisions contained herein may be subject to disciplinary action.
(Ord. 1564(A), passed 3-10-08)
ARTICLE 114: POLITICAL ACTIVITIES PROHIBITED BY APPOINTED PERSONS
§ 114.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   MUNICIPAL OFFICE. Those offices set forth in Article III, 2(a) through (j)
of the Charter of the City of Weirton.
(Ord. 1565(A), passed 3-10-08)
§ 114.02 POLITICAL ACTIVITY.
   (A)   No person appointed to any municipal office shall:
      (1)   Directly or indirectly give, solicit or receive, or in any manner
be concerned in giving, soliciting or receiving any assignment, subscription,
or contribution for or against any political campaign or candidate for Mayor or
City Council.
      (2)   Engage in any political activity of any kind or nature for or
against any candidate for Mayor or City Council.
      (3)   Take part in the management, affairs or political campaigns for or
against any candidate for Mayor or City Council.
   (B)   The provisions in division (A) above do not apply to any person who is
himself or herself a candidate for Mayor or City Council and shall not impede
any persons' right as a citizen to cast his or her vote. Further, said
provisions do not prohibit a person appointed to any municipal office from
campaigning for or against any county or municipal ordinance or resolution, or
any state, county or local levy, issue, referendum, ballot initiative, charter
amendment or constitutional amendment.
(Ord. 1565(A), passed 3-10-08) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty or a
misdemeanor and jailed for up to 30 days or fined up to the sum of $500, plus
court costs, or both.
(Ord. 1565(A), passed 3-10-08)

ARTICLE 121: MAYOR
   (Reserved for future legislation)
ARTICLE 123: CITY MANAGER
§ 123.01 ADMINISTRATIVE SUPERVISION AND RULES.
   (A)   In exercising supervision over the various departments of the city,
the City Manager shall act through the officers in charge of the particular
departments, and such officers shall be directly responsible to the City
Manager for the efficient and economical operation of their departments. Such
officers shall perform the duties assigned to them by the Charter and this
article and such other duties as may be assigned to them by the administrative
rules of the City Manager. The City Manager shall have authority to suspend and
discipline city employees.
   (B)   The City Manager may issue administrative rules not inconsistent with
law, the Charter or this article, setting forth the general administrative
procedures of the city, and such rules shall be binding upon all departments,
officials and employees of the city. No person shall fail, neglect or refuse to
comply with such rules.
('71 Code, § 123.01)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 123.02 FULL-TIME POSITION.
   The City Manager shall devote his full time to his office and shall not
engage in any other occupation or hold any other office, except as otherwise
provided.
('71 Code, § 123.02)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 123.03 CLERKS.
   The City Manager shall have one or more clerks, who shall be appointed by
him. The City Manager's clerks shall perform such duties as the City Manager
may direct and shall work under his supervision and be directly responsible to
him. Such clerks shall receive such salaries as may be provided by Council.
('71 Code, § 123.03)
§ 123.04 ACTING CITY MANAGER.
   (A)   When a serving City Manager will not be able to exercise his or her
powers due to temporary absence for disability, vacation, or for other
legitimate purposes, he or she may designate a qualified city administrative
officer to exercise his or her duties during his or her temporary absence or
disability.
   (B)   When the City Manager designates another person to act, as set out in
division (A) above, the City Council may, by a majority vote, revoke this
designation and appoint another officer of the city to serve as City Manager
until the regularly appointed City Manager returns.
   (C)   In the event that the City Manager has not designated a replacement,
or if the office of City Manager is unoccupied, the City Council may, by
resolution, appoint a qualified officer or person of the city to perform the
duties of the City Manager until he or she shall return or until his or her
disability shall cease. In the case where there is no City Manager, the acting
City Manager shall serve until a new City Manager is appointed by the Mayor and
approved by the City Council.
(Ord. 1407, passed 11-10-03)
ARTICLE 125: CITY CLERK
   (Reserved for future legislation)
ARTICLE 127: ACCOUNTING AND TREASURY DEPARTMENT
§ 127.01 CITY FINANCIAL DIRECTOR; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Accounting and Treasury Department of the city shall, subject to the
provisions of
Article VII, § 1(3a) of the Charter, be under the supervision and the direction
of the City Financial Director, who shall also perform the duties and have the
powers of City Auditor.
('71 Code, § 127.01)
§ 127.02 OTHER OCCUPATIONS PERMITTED.
   The City Financial Director may engage in other occupations.
('71 Code, § 127.02)
§ 127.03 DUTIES OF THE DEPARTMENT.
   In addition to those powers and duties of the City Financial Director and
Auditor established by Article VII, § 5 of the Charter, the Accounting and
Treasury Department shall also have custody of city funds and investments.
('71 Code, § 127.03)
§ 127.04 COLLECTION OF MONEY; DEPOSITS AND DISBURSEMENTS.
   Moneys due to the city shall be paid to the City Financial Director, so far
as possible, and any moneys which may be received or collected by another
department, commission or officer shall be promptly transmitted to the City
Financial Director. All moneys so received, and any other funds of the city,
shall be deposited in the Peoples Bank, the Bank of Weirton, the Citizens Bank
of Weirton, the First National Bank of Weirton or any other bank which the City
Financial Director deems necessary to the credit of the proper fund, in the
manner provided by law, and shall be disbursed only upon checks or other
written orders signed or countersigned by the City Financial Director or signed
by the City Manager and countersigned by one of the City Financial Director’s
clerks or the City Clerk.
('71 Code, § 127.04) (Ord. 181, passed 7-12-65)
§ 127.05 CLERKS.
   The City Clerk shall act as the City Financial Director’s chief clerk. In
addition, the City Financial Director may have such additional clerks as the
City Manager may determine, who shall work under the City Financial Director’s
supervision and be directly responsible to him. Such additional clerks shall be
appointed by the City Manager, and shall receive such salaries as may be fixed
in the appropriation for the Accounting and Treasury Department.
('71 Code, § 127.05)
ARTICLE 129: LEGAL DEPARTMENT
§ 129.01 SUPERVISION BY CITY ATTORNEY.
   The Legal Department of the city shall, subject to the provisions of Article
VII, § 1(3a) of the Charter, be under the supervision and direction of the City
Attorney.
('71 Code, § 129.01)
§ 129.02 ADDITIONAL OCCUPATIONS AND COMPENSATION FOR CITY ATTORNEY.
   For any duties beyond those prescribed in §
129.03 of this code, the City Attorney shall receive such compensation as may
be provided by Council. He may engage in other occupations, except that he may
not act as attorney in any matter involving a claim against the city.
('71 Code, § 129.02)
§ 129.03 DUTIES.
   The Legal Department shall:
   (A)   Examine and approve all deeds, contracts and other legal instruments
to which the city is a party;
   (B)   Represent the city in all legal proceedings to which the city is a
party or in which it is interested, including criminal prosecutions and
proceedings before any quasi-judicial or administrative body or bureau;
   (C)   Advise and assist in the preparation of ordinances and rules;
   (D)   Advise other city officials and departments with respect to the legal
aspects of any proposed act or omission;
   (E)   Compromise or settle any claim, demand or suit by or against the city
or any department or agency thereof that may be interested; provided, however,
that if any such compromise or settlement shall require the payment by the city
of any sum in excess of $500, the approval of Council shall be required.
('71 Code, § 129.03)
§ 129.04 SUPPLIES AND STENOGRAPHIC ASSISTANCE.
   The City Manager shall furnish to the Legal Department such supplies and
stenographic assistance as the City Attorney may require. In addition, the City
Attorney shall be reimbursed by the city for such expenditures as he may make
in the performance of his duties, including court costs, witness fees and
stenographic expense.
('71 Code, § 129.04)
ARTICLE 131: POLICE DEPARTMENT
§ 131.01 CHIEF OF POLICE FULL-TIME POSITION.
   The Chief of Police shall devote his full time to his office and shall not
engage in any other occupation or hold any other office.
('71 Code, § 131.01)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 131.02 WEIRTON POLICE RESERVE.
   (A)   The Weirton Police Reserve is hereby established.
   (B)   The Weirton Police Reserve shall be organized and subject to such
rules and regulations as shall be approved by the Weirton Police Reserves and
the Police Chief.
   (C)   The Weirton Police Reserve shall render unpaid volunteer police
service from time to time as requested by the Mayor of the city or the Police
Chief. Members of the Weirton Police Reserve, while on duty, shall have such
arrest powers as are granted by and consistent with the statutes and common law
of the state.
   (D)   The Weirton Police Reserve, while on duty, shall wear such uniforms
and insignia as provided for in the rules and regulations of the Weirton Police
Reserve as approved by the Police Chief. Members of the Weirton Police Reserve
shall be furnished with such equipment as provided for by the rules and
regulations of the Weirton Police Reserve and the Police Chief. Any uniforms,
insignia or equipment issued by the city shall remain the property of the city.
   (E)   All members of the Weirton Police Reserve shall be subject to
suspension or dismissal for cause in the manner provided by the rules and
regulations of the Weirton Police Reserve as approved by the Police Chief.
   (F)   All rules and regulations of the Weirton Police Reserve shall become
effective, after adoption, only upon approval in writing by the Police Chief.
   (G)   The Weirton Police Reserve is hereby created for the purpose of
rendering assistance to the Police Department and it is expressly understood
that the establishment of the Weirton Police Reserve shall not in any way
affect the recruitment or employment of members of or by the paid Police
Department of the city.
('71 Code, § 131.02) (Ord. 241, passed 10-26-70)
§ 131.03 DUTIES.
   The Police Department shall, under the supervision of the Police Chief:
   (A)   Preserve the peace and order of the city;
   (B)   Protect persons and property from injury or harm;
   (C)   Arrest and apprehend persons suspected of crimes and misdemeanors;
   (D)   Regulate traffic;
   (E)   Enforce laws and ordinances;
   (F)   Cause to be served and executed any criminal process issued by any
court of competent jurisdiction in the city;
   (G)   Maintain proper records of criminal acts, criminals and arrests; and
   (H)   Have custody of lost and stolen property.
('71 Code, § 131.03)
Statutory reference:
   Additional powers and authority of policemen, see W. V. Code § 8-14-3
§ 131.04 MINIMUM WORK WEEK.
   The members of the Police Department of the city shall not be required to
attend to their duties for more than eight hours per day and for more than five
days per week; except, that any such member may be required to attend to his
duties for more than eight hours per day and more than five days per week on
the order of his superior officer, in the event of an emergency, as may be
prescribed by the Police Chief.
('71 Code, § 131.04)
§ 131.05 COMPLIANCE WITH RULES.
   It shall be unlawful for any member of the Police Department to fail,
neglect or refuse to comply with the rules and regulations for the Police
Department, as approved and adopted by Council.
('71 Code, § 131.05)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 131.06 POLICE CIVIL SERVICE CODE.
   (A)   There shall be a Police Civil Service Commission for the city. The
powers, duties, rules, regulations and other provisions applicable to such
Commission shall be the same as those provided for in W. V. Code §§ 8-14-
6 through 8-14-23. Such sections are hereby adopted by reference and shall be
known and designated as the “Police Civil Service Code.”
   (B)   The Police Civil Service Code has been amended in substance by the
following ordinances: Ordinance 459, passed 10-12-76, Ordinance 803, passed 12-
16-85, and Ordinance 1164, passed 3-24-97, all of which amend Rule VIII.
('71 Code, § 131.06)
Statutory reference:
   Policemen's pension and relief fund, see W. V. Code §§ 8-22-16 et seq.
Cross-reference:
   Amendments to Appendix A of the rules and regulations of the Police Civil
Service Commission, see §
131.08
§ 131.07 SPECIAL SCHOOL ZONE POLICE OFFICERS.
   (A)   The Mayor shall have the authority to appoint special school zone
police officers who shall control and direct traffic upon streets, avenues,
roads, alleys or ways at or near schools for the purpose of providing necessary
traffic control for the benefit of pupils and employees of such schools.
   (B)   Such special school zone police officers shall perform duties in such
zones as they shall be assigned to and they shall be vested with all the powers
of local police officers to perform such duties.
   (C)   All special school zone police officers shall serve at the will and
pleasure of the Mayor.
('71 Code, § 131.07) (Ord. 353, passed 11-13-73)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to provide school zone police officers, see W. V. Code § 8-14-5
§ 131.08 AMENDMENTS TO APPENDIX A OF THE RULES AND REGULATIONS OF THE POLICE
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION.
   (A)   Rule VIII of Appendix 8 of the rules and regulations of the Police
Civil Service Commission is hereby amended to read as follows:
   CONDUCT OF EXAMINATIONS
   A.   Applicants for the rank of probationary patrolman, unless applicant is
already a West Virginia Certified Law Enforcement Officer in Good Standing with
a Current Certification, must first take and pass the physical agility test
before taking the written test. Those applicants that take the written test
will be stacked in numerical order, highest to lowest, based off their test
scores. All qualified applicants shall then be graded on a scale of 100% of
which 60% of said grade shall be the written examination, and 40% of said grade
shall be by oral examination.
(Am. Ord. 1301, passed 10-10-00)
      Section 1. Examinations to be practical: All fitness tests shall be
practical in character, shall relate directly to those matters which will
fairly test the relative capacity of the person examined to discharge the
particular duties of the class of positions to which appointment is sought and
shall when appropriate include test of physical qualifications, health and
manual skills.
      Section 2. Content of examinations: The fitness test held to establish a
list of eligibles for any class shall consist of one or more of the following
parts:
         (a) Written test. This part when required shall include a written
demonstration designed to show the familiarity of competitors with knowledge
involved in the class of positions to which they seek appointment, their
ability in the use of English, the range of their general information or their
general educational attainments. A formal thesis upon one or more subjects may
be required if advisable.
         (b) Oral interview. This part when required shall include a personal
interview with applicants for position of probationary patrolman where ability
to deal with others, to meet the public or other personal qualifications are to
be determined. An oral test may also be used in examinations where a written
test is unnecessary or impracticable.
         (c) Performance tests. This part when required shall include such
tests of performance or trade as will determine the ability and manual skill of
competitors to perform the work involved.
         (d) Physical tests. This part when required shall consist of tests of
the bodily condition, muscular strength, agility and physical fitness of
competitors. This may be given a weight in examinations or may be used in
excluding from further examination applicants who do not measure up to the
minimum required standards. West Virginia Certified Law Enforcement Officers in
Good Standing with a Current Certification will not be required to participate
in the physical test portion.
(Am. Ord. 2071, passed 3-25-19)
         (e) Mental tests. This part when required shall include any tests to
determine intelligence, the general capacity of applicants to adjust their
thinking to new problems and conditions of life or to ascertain special
character traits and aptitudes.
         (f) Training and experience. This part when required shall be marked
from the statements of education and experience contained in the application
form or from such supplementary data as may be required. The commissioners, in
their discretion, may investigate the truth of competitors’ statements as to
training and experience and govern their rating accordingly.
      Section 3. Certified Law Enforcement Officers: Applicants who are already
certified West Virginia Law Enforcement Officers in Good Standing or are Out of
State Law Enforcement Officers in Good Standing with certifications that are
accepted by the West Virginia Law Enforcement Professional Standards Program
(LEPS) are subject to the following provisions:
         (a)   Physical Testing. Applicants who qualify under this section will
not be required to take any testing involving bodily condition, muscular
strength, agility and physical fitness.
         (b)   Probationary Period. Those applicants that meet the criteria in
this section will be placed on a one-year probationary period, but will not be
subject to the 10% less pay requirement during their probationary period.
         (c)   Personal Days. Three personal days will be given to applicants
to whom this section applies to.
         (d)   Sign-on Bonus. Applicants under this section who sign a 2-year
contract will receive a $10,000 sign-on bonus that will be paid over the course
of the 2-year contract period.
   B.   All applicants for examinations for promotions within the Police
Department from a lower grade to the next higher grade shall be required to
have completed at least two (2) years of service in the next lower grade before
they shall be eligible for promotion, except for the Chief of Police (WV 8-14-
17). Applicants for promotion shall be graded on a scale of points determined
by experience of service and written competitive examinations.
      Section 1. Written Examination. This part shall consist of such number of
questions as may be set forth by the Commission, based upon subjects designed
to show the familiarity of competitors with the knowledge involved in the class
of position to which they seek promotion. The applicant having the highest
number of correct answers within the testing group for that rank shall receive
one hundred (100) promotion points. All written examinations will be obtained
from an approved source and will be graded by said approved source.
      Section 2. Experience. For the purposes of this section, experience shall
be determined to be the applicant’s longevity within the Weirton Police
Department. Credit for seniority shall be given only for actual service whether
such service has been continuous or not. Seniority shall be computed as of the
date of examination as follows:
      For the first full year   1 point
      For each full year of completed service thereafter, one additional point.
      Section 3. The written examination will be graded on a bell curve system.
      After receipt of the results of the written examination from the
examination source, the commission will open the results in the presence of two
members of the Fraternal Order of Police who have been designated by the
Fraternal Order of Police as observers, if the Fraternal Order of Police
desires the presence of observers. The commission will grade the results by
using the bell curve and will then post the results for the entire examination.
      Section 4. All applicants for promotion to a position in the Weirton
Police Department who have passed the competitive examination specified above
shall before being appointed or promoted, undergo a medical examination which
shall be conducted under the supervision of a board composed of two doctors of
medicine appointed for such purpose by the appointing officer of the City.
   C.   Rules applicable to all classes of applicants:
      The actual conduct of every examination shall be under the responsible
direction of the commission, or its designated agents, free from interference,
participation or influence of the appointing officer, or of any person other
than the examiner and experts, employed by the commission, and the commission
is hereby authorized to employ such assistance or experts, and for this purpose
may exempt from examination under these rules, any person engaged in private
business who shall render it any professional, scientific, technical or other
expert service of an occasional or exceptional character.
      All examinations shall be impartial, fair, and practical, and designed to
test the relative qualifications and fitness of applicants to discharge the
duties of the particular position which they seek to fill. No question in any
examination shall relate to the political or religious convictions or
affiliations of the applicant. (Ord. 880, passed 9-12-88; Am. Ord. 943, passed
5-13-91; Am. Ord. 1012, passed 2-8-93; Am. Ord. 1021, passed 4-12-93; Am. Ord.
2071, passed 3-25-19; Am. Ord. 2226, passed 4-8-24)
   (B)   Rule IX of Appendix A of the rules and regulations of the Police Civil
Service Commission is hereby amended to read as follows:
   Rule IX
   Eligible list.
   Section 1. Posting of lists: From the returns of each examination, the
commission shall prepare and keep open to public inspection, an eligible list
of the persons who are eligible. Such persons shall be notified and take rank
upon the eligible list in the order of their relative grades without reference
to priority of time and examination.
   Whenever it becomes necessary to hold a subsequent examination in order to
obtain additional eligibles, the commission may consolidate existing lists for
the same class by rearranging the eligible names therein according to their
grades. All persons whose names appear on an existing list which is to be
merged with a new list shall have an opportunity to compete in the second
examination.
   Section 2. Duration of the lists: The term of eligibility for each eligible
list shall be as follows:
   A.   Probationary list of eligibles shall be valid for a period of three (3)
years after certification by the commission.
   B.   Promotional lists of eligibles shall be valid for a period of one (1)
year after the certification by the commission.
   Section 3. Where examinations are held, only the grades of the successful
candidate or candidates will be released. The commission will seal up the
grades of all unsuccessful candidates and such grades shall not be made public
and will be filed away for the sole use of the members of the commission.
(Ord. 881, passed 9-12-88)
ARTICLE 133: FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 133.01 SUPERVISION BY FIRE CHIEF.
   The Fire Department shall, subject to the provisions of Article VII, § 1(3a)
of the Charter, be under the supervision and direction of the Fire Chief.
('71 Code, § 133.01)
§ 133.02 DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Fire Chief shall be the commanding officer of the Fire Department and
shall assign and supervise the work of all members of the Fire Department.
('71 Code, § 133.02)
§ 133.03 FIRE CHIEF; OTHER GOVERNMENT WORK.
   The Fire Chief may engage in other government work assigned by the City
Manager.
('71 Code, § 133.03)
§ 133.04 DUTIES OF THE DEPARTMENT.
   The Fire Department shall, under the supervision of the Fire Chief:
   (A)   Combat fires within the city limits;
   (B)   Inspect and abate fire hazards;
   (C)   Prevent the occurrence of fires; and
   (D)   Maintain records of fires and related matters.
('71 Code, § 133.04)
Statutory reference:
   Authority of Council to prevent fires, see W. V. Code § 8-15-1
§ 133.05 AUTHORITY DURING FIRE.
   The Fire Chief, or any member of the Fire Department, who is in command at a
fire, shall have the authority to direct the removal of combustible material
and the demolition of buildings and structures when, in his opinion, it is
necessary to prevent the spread of the fire.
('71 Code, § 133.05)
§ 133.06 COMPLIANCE WITH RULES.
   No member of the Fire Department shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply
with the rules and regulations for the Fire Department, as approved and adopted
by Council.
('71 Code, § 133.06)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Statutory reference:
   Hours of duty for firemen, see W. V. Code § 8-15-10
§ 133.07 FIREMEN'S CIVIL SERVICE CODE.
   (A)   There shall be a Firemen's Civil Service Commission for the city. The
powers, duties, rules, regulations and other provisions applicable to such
Commission shall be the same as those provided for in W. V. Code §§ 8-15-11
through 8-15-27. Such sections are hereby adopted by reference and shall be
known and designated as the “Firemen's Civil Service Code.”
   (B)   The Firemen's Civil Service Code has been amended in substance by the
following ordinances: Ordinance 648, passed 5-11-81, which amends Rule VIII,
Section 3; and Ordinance 708, passed 8-18-83, which amends Rule III, Section 9.
('71 Code, § 133.07)
Statutory reference:
   Firemen's pension and relief fund, see W. V. Code §§ 8-22-16 et seq.
§ 133.08 FIRE CHIEF UNDER CIVIL SERVICE.
   The office of Fire Chief shall come under the provisions of W. V. Code §§ 8-
15-11 through 8-15-27 which pertain to civil service for paid fire departments.
('71 Code, § 133.08) (Res. passed 1-17-62)
§ 133.09 AMENDMENT TO APPENDIX C, RULE VIII, SECTION OF THE RULES AND
REGULATIONS OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   Rule VIII (8) of Appendix C of the rules and regulations of the Fire Civil
Service Commission is hereby amended to read as follows:
   A.   Written Examination. This part shall consist of such number of
questions as may be set forth by the Commission, based upon subjects designed
to show the familiarity of competitors with the knowledge involved in the class
of position to which they seek promotion. The applicant having the highest
number of correct answers within the testing group for that rank shall receive
one hundred (100) promotion points. All written examinations will be obtained
from an approved source and will be graded by said approved source.
   B.   Experience. For the purposes of this section, experience shall be
determined to be the applicant's longevity within the Weirton Fire Department.
Credit for seniority shall be given only for actual service whether such
service has been continuous or not. Seniority shall be computed as of the date
of examination as follows:
   For the first full year   1 year
   For each full year of completed service thereafter, one additional point.
   C.   The written examination will be graded on a bell curve system.
   After receipt of the results of the written examination from the examination
source, the Commission will open the results in the presence of two (2) members
of the Weirton Fire Fighters Association, Local #948, who have been designated
by the Weirton Fire Fighters Association, Local #948, as observers, if the
Weirton Fire Fighters Association, Local #948, desires the presence of
observers. The Commission will grade the results by using the bell curve and
will then post the results for the entire examination.
   D.   All applicants for promotion to a position in the Weirton Fire
Department who have passed the competitive examination specified above shall
before being appointed or promoted, undergo a medical examination which shall
be conducted under the supervision of a board composed of two doctors of
medicine appointed for such purpose by the appointing officer of the City.
   E.   Each candidate for fireman must pass the civil service examination with
a minimum score of seventy percent (70%).
   F.   Five (5) additional points shall be added to the score of any active
volunteer fireman within the Weirton Division who has taken the civil service
examination to be a fireman if that fireman meets the minimum standards for
West Virginia Firefighter 1 and has a minimum of one (1) year’s service in the
Volunteer Division. To be considered an “active” volunteer fireman, the fireman
must have attended at least fifteen percent (15%) of all the call-outs and
drills which occurred within the year next previous to the day he or she took
the civil service examination.
   G.   Reserved.
   H.   A person who is both an honorably discharged member of any of the
United States military services and who qualifies for the veterans’ preference
and the Purple Heart preference under W.V. Code §6-13-1 and who is in addition
an active volunteer fireman within the Weirton Division shall be entitled to
the veteran’s preferences and the five (5) point preference mentioned in
section F above.
   I.   Every new fireman hired under the provisions of the rules and
regulations of the Fire Department shall complete Emergency Medical Technician
training within his or her one (1) year probationary period.
   J.   Every fireman hired after the active date of the adoption of this rule
shall maintain his or her Emergency Medical Technician status while employed
with the Department as a condition of employment.
(Ord. 1019, passed 5-10-93; Am. Ord. 1451, passed 7-11-05)
