ARTICLE 155: PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 155.01 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   (A)   There shall be a City Planning Commission which shall consist of nine
members, all of whom shall be freeholders and residents of the city; who shall
be qualified by knowledge and experience in matters pertaining to the
development of the city; who shall include representatives of business,
industry and labor; four of such members shall have been residents of the city
at least 10 years prior to the appointment. Members shall be appointed by the
Mayor with the consent and approval of Council.
   (B)   One member of the Commission must be a member of the municipal
governing body or a designee and one member must be a member of the
administrative department of the municipality or a designee. The term of
membership for these two members is the same as their term of office.
   (C)   The City Engineer shall henceforth be an advisory member of the Board.
('71 Code, § 155.01) (Ord. 468, passed 1-10-77; Am. Ord. 918, passed 2-13-90;
Am. Ord. 1472, passed 12-12-05; Am. Ord. 1480, passed 3-13-06)
Statutory reference:
   Municipal planning commissions, see W. V. Code §§ 8-24-1 et seq.
§ 155.02 POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Planning Commission shall have such powers and perform such duties and
functions as may be vested in or required of the Planning Commission under
state law.
('71 Code, § 155.02)
Statutory reference:
   Preparation of comprehensive plan, see W. V. Code §§ 8-24-16 et seq.
§ 155.03 RULES, REGULATIONS AND BYLAWS.
   The Planning Commission shall adopt rules, regulations and bylaws
prescribing the duties of its members and committees and providing for such
other matters as are now or may hereafter be authorized by law.
('71 Code, § 155.03)
§ 155.04 PLANS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF CITY.
   The Planning Commission generally shall develop and prepare plans for the
development of the city and of any land outside of the city which, in the
opinion of the Commission, bears a relation to the planning of the city. Such
plans, so far as possible, shall provide for the location and character of
public buildings and improvements, streets and roads, parks and parkways,
recreation areas, bridges, tunnels, railroad crossings, street lighting
systems, sewerage and water supply systems and public housing projects.
('71 Code, § 155.04)
§ 155.05 COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS; OTHER OCCUPATIONS ALLOWED.
   Members of the Planning Commission shall serve as such without compensation
and may engage in other occupations.
('71 Code, § 155.05)
§ 155.06 CHAIRMAN.
   The City Planning Commission shall annually elect its own Chairman from its
membership.
('71 Code, § 155.06)
§ 155.07 CITY ENGINEER AS TECHNICAL ADVISER.
   The City Engineer, unless he is a member of the Planning Commission, shall
act as technical adviser to the Commission and shall participate in
determinations which it may make.
('71 Code, § 155.07)
§ 155.08 PLANS AND PLATS.
   Council shall take no action authorizing or approving the construction or
alteration of any street, park, playground or other public area or any public
building or improvement, without first submitting the plans therefor to the
Planning Commission for its investigation and report. All plans, plats and
replats of land laid out in building lots, and the streets to be dedicated to
public use, shall be submitted to the Commission for consideration, and no such
plan, plat or replat shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of the County
Courts of Brooke or Hancock Counties, unless it bears the endorsement that it
has been submitted to the Planning Commission, has been submitted by it to the
Mayor and Council and has been approved by the Mayor and Council.
('71 Code, § 155.08)
§ 155.09 SUPPLIES AND PERSONNEL GENERALLY.
   The City Manager shall furnish to the Planning Commission such supplies and
personnel as he may determine to be necessary for the performance by the
Commission of its duties under this article.
('71 Code, § 155.09)
§ 155.10 ENGINEERS AND CLERKS.
   The Planning Commission shall have the power to employ such engineers and
clerks as it may deem necessary.
('71 Code, § 155.10)
§ 155.11 BUDGET AND APPROPRIATION.
   To meet the expenses incident to the performance by the Planning Commission
of its duties, the Planning Commission shall submit a budget therefor to
Council for each fiscal year. Council shall consider such budget and make such
appropriation to the Commission as Council deems proper.
('71 Code, § 155.11)
ARTICLE 159: MUNICIPAL BUILDING COMMISSION
§ 159.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS; TERM.
   (A)   There is hereby created and established a municipal building
commission which shall be known as the Weirton Municipal Building Commission.
The Commission shall be a public corporation and, as such, shall have perpetual
existence. All property, powers and duties and the management and control of
the Commission shall be vested in a Board which shall consist of five members
who shall be appointed by Council. All members of the Board shall be appointed
for terms of five years. Prior to making the initial appointments to the Board,
Council shall make such initial appointments so that approximately one-fifth of
the total number of members of the Board shall be appointed for a term of one
year, approximately one-fifth of the total number of members of the Board shall
be appointed for a term of two years, approximately one-fifth of the total
number of members of the Board shall appointed for a term of three years,
approximately one-fifth of the total number of members of the Board shall be
appointed for a term of four years, and approximately one-fifth of the total
number of members of the Board shall be appointed for five years. As the term
of each such initial appointee expires, the successor to fill the vacancy
created by such expired term shall be appointed for a term of five years.
   (B)   If any member of the Board dies, resigns or for any reason ceases to
be a member of the Board, Council shall appoint another individual to fill the
unexpired portion of the term of such member. No more than two-thirds of the
total number of members of the Board shall be from the same political party,
and no member of the Board shall hold any office, other than the office of
notary public, or employment under the United States of America, the State of
West Virginia, any county or political subdivision thereof, or any political
party. All members of the Board shall be residents of the city. No member of
the Board shall receive any compensation for his services as such, but each
member shall be reimbursed by the Commission for any reasonable and necessary
expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his duties as a member of the
Board.
(Ord. 1196, passed 10-14-97)
Statutory reference:
   Power to establish, see W. V. Code Art. 8-33
§ 159.02 POWERS; DUTIES.
   The Municipal Building Commission shall have all the powers and duties that
are granted to a municipal building commission under West Virginia Code Article
8-33 as fully and to the same extent as if the powers and duties were fully set
out in this article.
(Ord. 1196, passed 10-14-97)
§ 159.03 INDEBTEDNESS.
   No constitutional or statutory limitation with respect to the nature or
amount of or rate of interest on indebtedness which may be incurred by the city
as a municipality shall apply to the indebtedness of the Municipal Building
Commission. No indebtedness of any nature of the Commission shall constitute an
indebtedness of the city or a charge against any property of the city. No
indebtedness or obligation incurred by the commission shall give any right
against any member of Council. The rights of creditors of the Commission shall
be solely against the Commission as a corporate body and shall be satisfied
only out of property held by it in its corporate capacity.
(Ord. 1196, passed 10-14-97)
§ 159.04 APPLICATION OF STATE CODE PROVISIONS.
   All of the provisions of West Virginia Code Article 8-33 relating to
Building Commissions, in force and effect as of the date of the enactment of
this article are hereby accepted and incorporated by reference herein and made
a part hereof.
(Ord. 1196, passed 10-14-97)
ARTICLE 161: WATER BOARD
§ 161.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The Weirton Area Water Board (the "Water Board") is hereby created and the
management, control and operation of the system, as it shall exist from time to
time, shall be vested in the Water Board, hereby created and appointed and
functioning as hereinafter provided.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.02 REQUIREMENTS.
   The Water Board shall consist of five persons, who are all customers of the
Weirton water system, and all of whom shall be residents of the state of West
Virginia of outstanding reputation, ability and integrity. All Boardmembers
shall be appointed by the Council and may or may not be Councilmembers,
officers or employees of the city.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.03 TERMS; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION.
   The Mayor shall notify all appointees of their appointment. The terms of
such Boardmembers first appointed shall be for one, two, three, four, and five
years, respectively, from the first day of the month in which appointed. In the
event of a vacancy and also within 30 days after the expiration of the term of
office of any Boardmember, a successor shall be appointed by the Council. All
vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term only and all other
appointments shall be for a term of five years, to commence on the date
following the scheduled expiration date of the previous term. The Water Board
shall have power to adopt bylaws, rules and regulations for its own government.
Any Boardmember shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his
or her term. The Boardmembers shall each receive compensation for their
services at the rate of $50 per meeting attended, not to exceed $150 per month,
and in addition, shall be reimbursed for any and all actual expenses incurred
in the performance of duties as ordered by the Water Board.(Ord. 1317, passed
6-11-01)
§ 161.04 OFFICERS.
   At the first meeting of the Water Board and annually thereafter, it shall
organize by designating one of the Boardmembers to act as Chairman and another
to act as Vice Chairman, and by designating a Secretary and a Treasurer, who
need not be members of the Water Board. The Secretary and Treasurer may be the
same person. The Chairman shall preside at all meetings when present and shall
call special meetings on his or her own motion, or when requested to do so by
any two Boardmembers. The Vice Chairman shall preside in the absence of the
Chairman. Three Boardmembers shall constitute a quorum, but any action to be
taken by the Water Board must be approved by not less than three Boardmembers.
The Secretary shall keep a written record of the proceedings which shall be
available for inspection as other municipal records. The Treasurer shall
receive and disburse the funds of the system as directed by the Water Board. In
the event that any Boardmember shall be unable to fulfill the duties of his or
her office for a period of six months, a majority of the remainder of the said
Boardmembers may declare the office of such Boardmember vacant, and the Council
shall thereupon fill such vacancy as otherwise provided for herein.(Ord. 1317,
passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.05 SYSTEM MANAGEMENT.
   The Water Board shall have full and complete authority for the supervision,
management, control and operation of the system, including the maintenance,
operations, improvements and extensions thereof. All bills for water service
shall be collected and accounted for by the Water Board in the manner and form
required by law, the Public Service Commission of West Virginia and the
ordinances of the city, and all disbursements and accounts of the system shall
be ordered paid out only upon approval of the Water Board; provided, however,
that all such supervision, management and control of the system and the
collection and accounting for bills for water and sewer service shall be
consistent and in accordance with any ordinances pursuant to which the city may
have authorized and issued any bonds from time to time outstanding, which by
their terms are payable from and secured by the revenues of the system. The
Water Board shall have the power and authority to make all contracts,
agreements and other matters necessary or proper for the full and complete
supervision, management and control of the system.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.06 BUDGET.
   The Water Board shall have power to fix and maintain a separate budget, and
employ, fix the compensation of and discharge a manager and all employees of
the system; provided, however, that the Water Board shall employ, fix the
compensation of and discharge a joint city/Water Board employee only with the
approval of the Council. The Chairman and Treasurer of the Water Board, upon
their appointment and taking office, shall furnish and file with the Recorder,
a bond in an amount to be set by the Water Board from time to time, the cost of
such bond to be payable from revenues of the system and such bond to be payable
to the city and conditioned as to the faithful performance of their respective
duties as are fixed by the Water Board.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.07 REPORTS.
   The Water Board shall provide reports, at least annually, or as otherwise
required by law, to the Mayor and Council indicating the system's financial
condition. The Water Board shall also provide the city with yearly audited
financial statements of the system, minutes of all meetings of the Water Board,
an annual budget for the system, and other information as may reasonably be
requested.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.08 ASSETS; LIABILITIES; PERSONNEL POLICIES.
   All assets and liabilities of the system, including accounts receivable and
accounts payable, and all employees thereof, shall be under the management and
control of the Water Board. Personnel policies and practices, and other matters
affecting employees of the Water Board shall, to the extent practicable and
unless otherwise approved by the Council, be the same as those undertaken by
the city, subject to the provisions of § 161.06.(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
§ 161.09 PURPOSE.
   The Council of the city enacts this article for the assurance and protection
of the citizens of the city and for the purpose of assuring the holders of the
bonds of the city payable from the income and revenues of the system of an
efficient operation and maintenance thereof. No amendment or repeal of this
article shall be enacted unless approved by 75% of the members of the Council
of the city. Any such amendment or repeal shall otherwise be enacted in
accordance with the rules and regulations of the Council of said city.
(Ord. 1317, passed 6-11-01)
ARTICLE 163: CITIZENS WITH DISABILITIES ADVISORY COMMISSION
§ 163.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The city hereby forms, creates, and establishes a commission to be known as
the Citizens with Disabilities Advisory Commission.
(Ord. 1483, passed 5-8-06)
§ 163.02 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Citizens with Disabilities Advisory Commission shall consist of a
minimum of seven members who shall be recommended by the Mayor and affirmed by
the City Council. At least two members of the Commission shall have a
disability. All members shall be residents of the city. One member of City
Council shall also serve on the Commission.
(Ord. 1483, passed 5-8-06; Am. Ord. 1612, passed 9-8-08)
§ 163.03 TERM; VACANCIES.
   Two of the original appointments shall serve for a term of one year; two for
a term of two years; and three for a term of three years. Following the
expiration of the terms of these original appointments, all succeeding
appointments shall be for terms of three years. All vacancies for the unexpired
terms of any members shall be for the period of said member’s term.
(Ord. 1483, passed 5-8-06; Am. Ord. 1612, passed 9-8-08)
ARTICLE 165: HALL OF FAME COMMITTEE
§ 165.01 ESTABLISHMENT; SELECTION CATEGORIES.
   (A)   Purpose. To establish a Hall of Fame Committee to honor former and
current Weirton residents for outstanding accomplishments (see §
165.09) in specific areas of endeavors and to administer the selection and
award processes.
   (B)   Committee name. The Committee shall be designated as the Weirton Hall
of Fame Committee.
   (C)   Selection categories. For purposes of selection and designation of
honorees for their endeavors, the nominations will be divided into the
following six categories:
      (1)   Philanthropy.
      (2)   Public service.
      (3)   Music and fine arts.
      (4)   Business, industry and professions.
      (5)   Education and religion.
      (6)   Sports and athletics.
(Ord. 1573, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.02 COMMITTEE OPERATION; COMPENSATION.
   (A)   Committee operation. The Committee shall conduct their meetings
according to Roberts' Rules of Order, and minutes of Committee meetings shall
be taken and provided to Council. During the initial orientation meeting, the
City Manager or his or her designee, shall assist the Committee in the
selection of a chairperson and secretary.
   (B)   Compensation.
      (1)   Members of the Committee shall receive no salary or compensation
for their services. The Committee will be funded by Council and expenditures
will be approved by Council and processed by the Chief Financial Officer of the
city.
      (2)   In addition to Council's funding, the Committee may also receive/
solicit contributions from individuals, corporations, associations, foundations
or other charitable organizations in the form of donations and the selling of
advertising in the event program and may apply for and receive grants from
federal or state agencies for the purposes of the Committee's established
purposes. Funds received from any of these sources will be used solely for the
Hall of Fame's purpose.
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.03 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Hall of Fame Committee shall consist of nine members. Each Councilperson
will appoint one member for the Committee and the Mayor will appoint two
members, with one member being a Councilperson. The member appointments will
not require approval by the Mayor or the other City Council members. Any
appointment to the Committee must be a current resident of the city for a
minimum of five years.
(Ord. 1573, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.04 APPOINTMENT; MEETINGS.
   (A)   The initial Committee appointees will be appointed as follows: one-
third will receive a four year term, one-third will receive a three year term
and one-third will receive a two year term. Upon the completion of the term,
succeeding appointments will be made for three years for all members. The
initial term of appointments will be determined by a drawing to allow the Mayor
and City Council to know the duration of the terms and their appointees will be
asked to serve. Should a Committee member not fulfill their term, the
appropriate Councilperson or the Mayor will appoint a replacement to serve the
remaining period of the term.
   (B)   The meeting schedule and attendance requirements are to be established
by the Committee.
(Ord. 1573, passed 4-7-08; Am. Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.05 NOMINATION AND SELECTION OF HALL OF FAME HONOREE REQUIREMENTS;
ELIGIBILITY.
   (A)   Honoree nominations can be made for individuals with "outstanding"
accomplishments starting with the incorporation of the City of Weirton (1947).
Achievements prior to this timeframe will not be considered for the selection
to the Hall.
   (B)   Eligibility for nomination will require a minimum of five years of
continuance residence within the boundaries of the City of Weirton (for
clarification purposes, those individuals having just a post office box in
Weirton will not qualify).
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.06 METHOD OF NOMINATIONS.
   (A)   Nomination forms will be printed and made available to the community
by the Committee. Nominations will be accepted during the period of September 1
to December 1 of each year. Each nomination must state the reason for the
nomination, give a biographical story and list the major accomplishments of the
individual being nominated. Failure to provide this documentation will exclude
the nomination from further consideration.
   (B)   All nominations must be in writing and signed and dated by the
individual making the nominations. Should nomination forms be received without
a signature, it will receive no further consideration.
   (C)   Nominations will be accepted by anyone.
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.07 SELECTION PROCESS.
   (A)   Starting December 1, the Committee will review the nomination forms,
investigate the nominees' accomplishments and select the honorees by February 1
of each year. In order for a nominee to be selected to the Hall, he or she must
receive a favorable vote by a minimum of seven members of the Committee.
   (B)   The date, place and manner of the recognition will be established by
the Committee. The Committee will then notify Council accordingly. The
presentation of awards and recognition of honorees will occur each spring.
   (D)   The maximum number of Honorees selected in any category each year will
be two. Also, Honorees can be selected to the Hall in only one category.
However, nominees can be nominated in more than one category for voting
purposes. If an Honoree is elected in more than one category, the Committee
will make the final decision as to the category to be used for recognition
purposes.
   (E)   The list of nominations received by the Committee shall be kept
confidential and shall not be made public. This stipulation is made to avoid
any possible embarrassment to those who are not selected and to help prevent
Committee members from having to justify their selections to the general
public.
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.08 FUTURE CHANGES.
   Future policies and procedures changes for the Weirton Hall of Fame
Committee can only be changed with formal approval of the Mayor and Council.
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)
§ 165.09 OUTSTANDING ACCOMPLISHMENT DEFINITION; SELECTION GUIDELINES.
   (A)   The definition of "outstanding accomplishment" and the criteria for
Committee members to use in the selection of Honorees should be established
during the initial meeting of the Committee
   (B)   It is the strong belief of the Study Committee that the integrity of
the selection process, future Committee members focus their decisions for
selection on the "outstanding accomplishment" aspect of the nominees. Clearly,
there will be years when only one or two nominees are made in a category and
this should not necessarily mean they are automatically selected to the Hall.
(Ord. 1766, passed 1-13-14)

ARTICLE 171: POLICE COURT
§ 171.01 RESERVED.
§ 171.02 POLICE JUDGE TO BE JUSTICE AND CONSERVATOR OF THE PEACE.
   The Police Judge shall be, ex officio, a justice and a conservator of the
peace, with authority to issue process for all offenses committed within the
police jurisdiction of the city, of which a justice of the peace has
jurisdiction under the state statutes, and for all violations of the provisions
of the codified ordinances and other ordinances of the city.
('71 Code, § 171.02)
§ 171.03 AUTHORITY OF POLICE JUDGE.
   The Police Judge may commit persons charged with a felony or misdemeanor to
jail or take bond for their appearance before the grand jury of the Circuit
Court of Hancock County or Brooke County, depending on which court has
jurisdiction of the offense charged.
('71 Code, § 171.03)
§ 171.04 OTHER OCCUPATIONS OF POLICE JUDGE.
   The Police Judge may engage in other occupations, but he shall not hold any
other office under the laws of the state or the city.
('71 Code, § 171.04)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 171.05 JURISDICTION.
   The Police Court shall have such jurisdiction as may be provided by law and
by the Charter.
('71 Code, § 171.05)
§ 171.06 SESSIONS; DOCKETS.
   There shall be regular sessions of the Police Court, at stated hours, to be
fixed by the Police Judge. Regular dockets, properly indexed and numbered,
shall be maintained with respect to all proceedings before the Police Court.
('71 Code, § 171.06)
§ 171.07 CLERK.
   There shall be a Clerk of the Police Court, who shall be employed as a
civilian employee by the City Manager, as provided for by the provisions for
employment in the Charter. He shall have the authority, under the laws of the
state, to administer oaths and shall issue and sign all summonses, processes
and other documents required by law or by order of the Police Court, which do
not require the Police Judge's signature. He shall collect all fines, fees and
forfeitures imposed by the Police Court or by ordinance, and transmit the same
daily to the City Financial Director, properly authenticated.
('71 Code, § 171.07)
§ 171.08 COURT COSTS; DOCKET FEE.
   (A)   The Police Court Clerk shall tax, in cases of conviction for violation
of any city ordinance of any person arrested, court costs in the amount of $6
for each case.
   (B)   The Police Court Clerk shall tax, in cases of conviction for violation
of any city ordinance of any person arrested, in addition to other fines, costs
and fees assessed as a result of convictions, a docket fee in the sum of $4 as
part of the costs for each person so convicted.
('71 Code, § 171.08) (Ord. 748, passed 6-11-84)
§ 171.09 FALSE SWEARING.
   No person shall swear falsely, under oath or affirmation lawfully
administered, in a trial of the witness or any other person.
('71 Code, § 171.09)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 61-5-2
§ 171.10 CONTEMPT OF COURT.
   The Police Court and the Judge thereof may issue attachment for contempt and
punish them summarily only in the following cases:
   (A)   Misbehavior in the presence of the court, or so near thereto as to
obstruct or interrupt the administration of justice;
   (B)   Violence or threats of violence to a judge or officer of the court, or
to a juror, witness or party going to, attending or returning from the court,
for or in respect of any act or proceeding had, or to be had, in such court;
   (C)   Misbehavior of an officer of the court in his official character;
   (D)   Disobedience to or resistance of any officer of the court, juror,
witness or other person to any lawful process, judgment, decree or order of
such court. The court shall not impose a fine for contempt, unless the
defendant be present in court, or shall have been served with a rule of the
court to show cause on some certain day, and shall have failed to appear and
show cause.
('71 Code, § 171.10)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 61-5-26
§ 171.11 AUTHORITY OF DEPUTY CLERK TO ISSUE WARRANTS; OATHS; BONDS.
   (A)   Pursuant to the authority granted by W. V. Code § 8-10-4, the Council
can vest in the Municipal Court Clerk and Deputy Municipal Court Clerks, the
authority to issue warrants for arrest, to administer oaths, and to accept and
approve sureties and bonds, in the absence of the Municipal Court Judge, and,
by this section, does hereby vest such authority in the Municipal Court Clerk
and Deputy Municipal Court Clerks.
   (B)   The salary of the Municipal Court Clerk shall remain as set by
Ordinance No. 1313, effective July 1, 2001.
   (C)   The salary of each Deputy Municipal Court Clerk shall be $200 per
month. The Deputy Municipal Court Clerk shall be considered a part-time
employee, and his or her duties and responsibilities shall be as set forth by
the City Manager or City Council.
   (D)   The appointment of the Municipal Court Clerk and Deputy Municipal
Court Clerks to perform the aforementioned duties shall be confirmed by City
Council; and whose terms shall be consistent with the existing terms of Council
to be reappointed with each new Council.
   (E)   Once appointed and confirmed to perform the aforementioned duties,
such authority shall only be removed by action of City Council.('71 Code, §
171.11) (Ord. 749, passed 6-11-84; Am. Ord. 1320, passed 7-9-01)
§ 171.12 JUROR FEES.
   (A)   Any person summoned to serve on a jury panel of the Weirton Municipal
Court shall be paid a juror fee of $10 per day and $0.20 per mile for
transportation to and from the juror's residence to the Weirton Municipal
Building.
   (B)   All fees and transportation costs paid to any person selected to serve
on a jury shall be charged to the defendant, if found guilty, as a court cost.
('71 Code, § 171.12) (Ord. 780, passed 3-27-85)

ARTICLE 191: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 191.01 ADDITIONAL FUNDING IN EMERGENCY GRANT SITUATION.
   (A)   Emergency grant funds will continue to have a maximum limit of $3,000
and will continue to be processed through the Selection Committee and the CDBG
staff committee to determine eligibility for funding.
   (B)   Additional funding will be available in an emergency situation under
the urgent need criteria on a case by case review basis.
   (C)   Additional funds will not be available for any persons if the
application is over one year old unless that person resubmits an application to
the Committee verifying eligibility and emergency status.
   (D)   The additional funding will require Selection Committee approval and
will only be available for those applicants who have been approved for the
original $3,000 grant money by the Selection Committee.
   (E)   The Selection Committee will consist of seven members, one from each
ward. If a Councilmember does not wish to be the representative from their
ward, they will appoint a member who is a resident of that ward. The CDBG
Director will chair the Committee and will have a tie breaking vote only. A
quorum is necessary to consider the approval valid.
   (F)   Members of the Selection Committee will be appointed for a one year
term ending June 30 at each year. In the event an opening arises in the middle
at a term or a new appointment is to be made, the Councilmember will notify the
CDBG Director of their choice in writing or by phone.
   (G)   The CDBG Staff Committee will continue to process all applications and
paperwork to determine the income eligibility of any applicant. Once
eligibility has been established, the applications will be turned over to the
Selection Committee for approval of funding.
(Ord. 1018, passed 4-12-93)
§ 191.02 RECOVERY OF TRANSPORTATION COSTS OF PRISONERS.
   When city officers transport any criminal defendant to or from the County
Courthouses at Wellsburg or New Cumberland, West Virginia, or to or from the
Northern Regional Jail, and that defendant is subsequently convicted of any
crime he or she was charged with, or of any lesser, included offense, or if the
charge is dismissed under circumstances which require the defendant to pay
court costs, then that defendant shall pay, as part of the court costs assessed
to him or her, an amount equal to the number of miles the defendant was
transported by city vehicles times the current mileage reimbursement rate for
one mile as provided at Internal Revenue Service Publication 535, or in any
legislation under that section.
(Ord. 1396, passed 11-10-03)
ARTICLE 193: D.U.I. CIVIL REIMBURSEMENT
§ 193.01 PURPOSE.
   The city finds that a significant number of traffic arrests and traffic
accidents in the city involve drivers who were operating a motor vehicle while
under the influence of alcoholic beverages and/or a controlled substance. In
addition, the city finds that in traffic accidents involving drivers who were
operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcoholic beverages and/
or a controlled substance there is a greater likelihood of personal injury and
property damage. As a result of these determinations, a greater operational
and/or financial burden is placed upon the city police, fire fighting and
rescue services by persons who are operating a motor vehicle while under the
influence of alcoholic beverages and/or a controlled substance.
(Ord. 1052, passed 12-13-93)
§ 193.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   EMERGENCY RESPONSE. This term shall mean:
      (1)   The providing, sending and/or utilizing public service, police,
fire fighting and rescue services by the city to an accident involving a motor
vehicle where one or more of the drivers were operating the motor vehicle while
under the influence of an alcoholic beverage and/or controlled substance.
      (2)   The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when
the driver was operating while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage or
a controlled substance.
   EXPENSE OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE. The fee associated with the occurrence of an
emergency response as set forth in the previous definition, whichever is
applicable, shall be $300.
(Ord. 1052, passed 12-13-93)
§ 193.03 LIABILITY.
   (A)   Liability for expenses.
      (1)   Any person who, while under the influence of an alcoholic beverage
or any controlled substance, or the combined influence of an alcoholic beverage
and any controlled substance, operates a motor vehicle which results in an
emergency response as defined in §
193.02 shall be responsible and/or liable for the expenses of the emergency
response. Those associated expenses shall become payable to the City Police
Department Special Revenue Fund. Those funds shall be earmarked to be used for
the maintenance and/or purchase of video equipment, breath testing equipment,
other police equipment, and other police related needs.
      (2)   For the purposes of the article, it shall be presumed that a person
was operating a motor vehicle under the influence of an alcoholic beverage if
chemical analysis of the drivers blood, breath, or urine indicates that the
amount of alcohol in the driver's blood was in excess of 0.07%.
   (B)   Civil liability. This article shall be construed to be a
responsibility and liability of a civil nature on the part of the driver and
shall not be construed to conflict, contravene or enlarge or reduce any
criminal liability or responsibility including fines imposed by a judge on a
driver for operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic
beverage and/or controlled substance.
(Ord. 1052, passed 12-13-93)
ARTICLE 195: MUNICIPAL SERVICE FEES
§ 195.01 TITLE.
   This subchapter shall be known and may be cited as the Weirton Municipal
Service Fee Ordinance of 2004.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.02 POLICY.
   (A)   The City Council finds that the city provides to all individuals
within its borders certain services, whether they are residents employed within
the city, or individuals living outside the city and employed within the
corporate boundaries of the city.
   (B)   The City Council finds that such services include public works, street
department functions, street maintenance, capital projects and public health
and safety.
   (C)   The City Council finds that such services are within the authority and
are the responsibility of the municipal government of the city as provided
under the general laws of the State of West Virginia.
   (D)   The City Council finds that since such services are essential to the
creation and maintenance of those jobs which provide livelihood to all
individuals employed within the city, as well as to the property interests of
residents and visitors to the city, it is therefore reasonable to derive a
portion of the cost of providing and maintaining such services from said
individuals.
   (E)   The City Council finds that W. V. Code § 8-13-13 provides that every
municipality has the plenary power and authority to provide by ordinance for
the installation, continuance, maintenance or improvement of such services, to
make reasonable regulations with respect thereto, and to impose by ordinance
upon the users of such services reasonable rates, fees and charges to be
collected in the manner prescribed by ordinance.
   (F)   The City Council finds that all of those individuals who use, enjoy
and benefit from these services should bear an equitable share of the costs
thereof. Council acknowledges that the Supreme Court of Appeals of West
Virginia has recognized that no system of assessing the costs will be
absolutely perfect and that municipalities are only required to install a
reasonable system of distributing the costs of all of the users that it can
reach through reasonable and prudent means and legislation.
   (G)   The City Council finds that the imposition of the Weirton Municipal
Service Fee established herein is a reasonable system for distributing the
costs to all users that the city can reach through reasonable and prudent means
and legislation.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUSINESS. All activities engaged in or caused to be engaged in with the
object of gain or economic benefit, either direct or indirect.
   CITY. The City of Weirton.
   DIRECTOR. The Finance Director of the city or his or her delegate.
   EMPLOYED.  Includes an employee working for an employer and/or a self-
employed individual working as a sole proprietor or member of a firm so as to
be subject to self-employment tax. An employee shall be considered employed in
a calendar week so long as such individual has not permanently discontinued
employment within the city.
   EMPLOYEE. One who works for an employer; a person working for a salary,
wages or compensation on a full-time or part-time basis at least 30 days per
calendar year.
   EMPLOYER.  One who employs the services of others; one for whom employees
work and who pays their wages or salaries, maintaining at least one regular
office or place of business within the city.
   FEE. The city service fee to be imposed by the provisions of this article.
   MUNICIPAL SERVICE or MUNICIPAL SERVICES. Any valuable service provided by
the city, its departments, boards, commissions and agents, which shall include,
but not be limited to street maintenance and improvement, street lighting, and
other valuable city services.
   TRANSIENT EMPLOYEE. An employee who remains for a short period of time and
their principal office is not within the municipality.
   USER. Any person who is employed within the city by an employer located
within the city and whose conduct is consistent with that of an employee
benefiting from the use of municipal services as stated in §
195.04.
   USER OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES. Any person, as defined in this section, who uses
any municipal service, as defined in this section, and who is found or declared
to be such a user in §
195.04.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.04 DECLARATION AS TO CONDUCT EVIDENCING THE USE OF A MUNICIPAL SERVICE.
   Council finds that holding employment with an employer with a place of
business located within the city for at least 30 days during a calendar year is
legal and valid proof of the use of one or more municipal services sufficient
to assess and collect a city service fee from the person engaging in the
activity stated. However, a transient employee whose principal office is out of
the city and either pays an employee user's fee or makes remuneration to
another municipality for services based upon employment shall be exempt. For
the purposes of this article, EMPLOYER shall include all for-profit and not-
for-profit entities and all local, county, state and federal governmental
entities.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.05 IMPOSITION OF CITY SERVICE FEE.
   (A)   Effective July 1, 2004 or as soon thereafter as all administrative
regulations are filed and distributed to employers within the city, there is
hereby imposed a city service fee to help defray the cost of providing and
maintaining city services within the city. The fee is hereby imposed upon any
person who is employed within the city and meets the requirements of a user of
municipal services as defined in §
195.03. Such person or persons shall be required to pay a city service fee of
$2 per calendar week.
   (B)   The Finance Director shall record and deposit these revenues as
defined in §
195.14.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.06 ADMINISTRATIVE REGULATIONS; INVESTIGATIONS AND POWERS TO AUDIT.
   (A)   Pursuant to W. V. Code § 8-13-13, the Director shall have the
authority and responsibility to promulgate reasonable regulations for the
collection of the fees imposed by this article. Said regulations shall include
but not be limited to:
      (1)   Regulations setting due dates for all fees.
      (2)   Regulations setting forth guidelines for the orderly collection of
the fees.
      (3)   Regulations requiring employers employing persons within the city
to collect and remit said fees and supply to the Director any and all
information which may include the following:
         (a)   The number of total employees;
         (b)   The number of transient employees;
         (c)   The number of full-time/part-time employees;
         (d)   Hire dates and termination dates for new employees or those who
have left employment;
         (e)   Names, social security numbers and addresses.
      (4)   Regulations requiring employers to collect from their employees and
to remit to the Division of Finance the fees imposed herein. Such rules,
regulations, and procedures shall be reduced to writing and shall take effect
upon being filed in the office of the City Clerk.
      (5)   The Finance Director, may, upon his/her discretion, allow employees
to submit information on an annual basis; however, payment of fees shall be
made quarterly.
      (6)   The method of reporting can be done by any means found to be
acceptable to the Director.
   (B)   For the purpose of ascertaining the correctness of any information
submitted to the Director as required by division (A) above, and for the
further purpose of conducting hearings as provided in §
195.10, the Director, or his/her designee, shall have the power to examine or
cause to be examined, any books, papers, records, memoranda, documents and any
other payroll data and information, and may take testimony and require material
proof with power to administer oaths to any person or persons from whom
testimony may be taken. The Mayor or Mayor's designee shall further have the
power to issue subpoenas and subpoenas duces tecum in the name of the city to
compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers,
records, memoranda, documents, and testimony at the time and place specified.
Every such subpoena and subpoena duces tecum shall be served at least five days
before the return date thereof by either personal service by any credible
person over 18 years of age or by registered or certified mail, return receipt
requested. A return receipt shall be required to prove service by registered or
certified mail. The Mayor or Mayor's designee shall have plenary power and
authority to further enforce the provisions of this article by instituting the
appropriate civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to W.
V. Code § 8-13-15.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.07 DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS.
   Each installment of the city service fee shall be due within 30 days from
the last day of the reporting period. Fees not received within 30 days of said
due date shall be considered delinquent. There shall be added to each
delinquent account a penalty of 5% of the balance thereof on the 31st day after
the reporting periods ends. Thereafter, a penalty of 2% shall be added to the
total outstanding balance at the end of each quarter. These penalties are
assessed against the employer.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.08 ENFORCEMENT.
   The City Attorney is charged with enforcement of this article and may
institute appropriate legal proceedings in the corporate name of the city and
against any employer who fails to collect or remit the fee imposed herein
pursuant to W. V. Code § 8-13-15.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.09 APPEAL BOARD.
   There is hereby established a City Service Fee Appeal Board consisting of
five members to include the Director of Administration and Finance, who shall
serve ex-officio and four persons employed within the city, two of whom shall
be chosen by Council and two of whom shall be chosen by the Mayor and all of
whom shall serve a two-year term to commence on July 1 and end on June 30 of
the second year following their appointments, provided that the initial
appointees shall serve a term to commence on July 1, 2004, the effective date
of this article and to end on June 30, 2006, Any member appointed to fill a
vacancy shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term. The Board shall
have the power to correct the amount of fees charged whenever there has been an
error of fact in the calculation of billing based upon evidence presented at a
protest hearing as provided in this article. The decision of the Board shall be
by a majority vote of all its members. The Board may, as to questions of law
arising in the course of a hearing, request a written opinion from the City
Attorney.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.10 PROTEST AND APPEAL.
   Any user who feels aggrieved by any charge to his or her city services fee
account may protest the same by filing written notice of such protest with the
Director setting forth his or her objections thereto and insuring the payment
of the assessed amount. The Director shall review such user's grounds for
appeal, render a decision on the protest and forthwith notify the user of such
decision in writing within 15 days of the filing of the protest. If the user is
still aggrieved, he may, within 15 days of the date of the Director's decision,
petition the City Service Fee Appeal Board, which shall set a date and time for
the hearing on the protest, which hearing shall be held within 30 days from the
filing of such appeal. The Appeal Board shall hear evidence relevant to the
protest and shall render its decision on the issues raised at such hearing
within 20 days after the hearing, giving notice of its decision in writing to
the user and the Director. The user may, within 30 days from the date of the
decision of the Board, file a petition, duly verified, with a court of
competent jurisdiction, requesting review of the Board's decision. If no such
petition is filed within 30 days, the decision of the Appeal Board shall become
final and conclusive. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the accrual
during the course of the appeal process of any penalty upon the balance of any
account ultimately found to be properly charged. A user's appeal shall not be
deemed to be upheld if the city or Board fails to meet a deadline contained
herein.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.11 EMPLOYER RESPONSIBILITY.
   It shall be the responsibility of all persons or firms employing persons
subject to the city service fee pursuant to § 195.03(A) and (D) to make
quarterly payment and complete reports when required to the Director pursuant
to regulations promulgated by the Director and pursuant to the provisions set
forth in this article.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.12 SEVERABILITY.
   If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, provision, sentence,
clause or word in this article is for any reason held invalid or
unconstitutional, such holding shall not affect the validity,
constitutionality, legality or application of any other portion of this
article.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.13 CONDITIONAL REPEALER OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS.
   In the event of the enactment of a statute by the legislature of the State
of West Virginia enabling municipalities in said state to impose a gross wage
tax upon all persons employed in such municipalities, or to impose any other
tax of a similar nature; and further, in the event that the city shall
thereafter impose, by ordinance, such a tax, such ordinance shall also provide
for the immediate repealer of this article, and such repealer shall operate to
discontinue the imposition of the city service fee imposed by this article.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.14 DEDICATION OF REVENUES.
   All revenues generated by the city service fee imposed herein are hereby
dedicated to public works projects, street department, street maintenance,
capital projects and public health and safety, and shall be deposited into a
designated revenue line item in the city's general fund. This dedication
follows the uniform chart of accounts as prescribed by the State Auditor under
the authority of W. V. Code § 6-9-2.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.15 FEE IMPOSED IN ADDITION TO POLICE AND FIRE SERVICE FEE.
   The fee imposed herein shall be in addition to and independent and exclusive
of the fire and police protection services fee.
(Ord. 1417, passed 3-8-04)
§ 195.16 ENJOINING INCREASES IN MUNICIPAL SERVICE FEE DURING CURRENT
ADMINISTRATION.
   The fee created in this article shall not be increased prior to June 30,
2011.
(Ord. 1537, passed 9-10-07)
ARTICLE 197: POLICE AND FIRE SERVICE FEE
§ 197.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DWELLING UNIT. One or more rooms, including a kitchen or kitchenette and
sanitary facilities, in a dwelling structure, designed as a unit for occupancy
by not more than one family.
   NONRESIDENTIAL BUILDING OR STRUCTURE. Those structures or building or part
(s) thereof that are used for any purpose listed in the City of Weirton Code,
Part XIII, Planning and Zoning Code, Section 703, Subsection “C” use classes 3,
4, 5, 7, 8 and 9. This includes places and other such non included titles/
definitions generally related to the term BUSINESS.
   OWNER-OCCUPANT. Includes any person, individual, firm, partnership, joint
venture, association, corporation, trust or any other group within the city
owning buildings or leasing/renting such buildings or structures and also
includes the owner or lessee of vehicles.
   RESIDENTIAL BUILDING OR STRUCTURE. A building or structure that a family
inhabits. This includes all buildings and structures or parts thereof, as
outlined in the City of Weirton Code, Part XIII, Planning and Zoning Code,
Section 703, Subsection “C”, Use Classes 1, 2 and 6. These lists are not to be
considered all inclusive.
   TOTAL SQUARE FEET. That sum as measured by the exterior dimensions of the
structure multiplied by the number of stories, but shall not include any part
of a structure encompassed by the following:
      (1)   Porches.
      (2)   Basements (when not utilized).
      (3)   Attics.
   VEHICLE. Includes automobiles, buses, recreational vehicles, trailers,
boats, motorcycles which are licensed under state law.
(Ord. 1354, passed 9-9-02)
§ 197.02 IMPOSITION OF POLICE AND FIRE PROTECTION CHARGE.
   (A)   There is hereby imposed upon the respective owners of all buildings or
structures in the city a police and fire protection fee or charge for the
period beginning July 1, 2000, and for each year thereafter, in an amount equal
to the total number of square feet contained in the building multiplied by
$0.15.
   (B)   The respective owners of all churches and schools or structures in the
city shall be exempt from the basic fee imposed in division (A) above, but
shall pay a police and fire fee protection charge or fee in the amount equal to
the total number of square feet contained in the building multiplied by $0.08.
   (C)   There is hereby imposed upon the respective owners or lessees of all
vehicles in the city a police and fire protection fee or charge for the period
beginning July 1, 2000 and for each year thereafter, a flat fee of $0 per
vehicle.
   (D)   The respective owners of all residential buildings or structures in
the city shall be exempt from the basic fee imposed in division (A) above, but
shall in lieu thereof pay a police and fire protection charge or fee for the
period beginning July 1, 2020 and for each year thereafter, a flat fee of $75
per residential building.
(Ord. 1354, passed 9-9-02; Am. Ord. 2105, passed 11-12-19)
§ 197.03 PAYMENT.
   All municipal police and fire service fees shall be paid in two equal
installments. The first installment payment will be due on September 30 of each
calendar year and become delinquent on October 1 of the same calendar year. The
second installment payment will be due March 31 of the following calendar year
and become delinquent on April 1 of that calendar year. If installments are not
paid on or before the respective due dates on which it becomes delinquent, a
penalty of 2% of the installment fee due shall be added and an additional 1% of
the installment fee shall be added for each succeeding 30 days elapsing before
payment is made.
(Ord. 1354, passed 9-9-02; Am. Ord. 1780, passed 9-8-14)
§ 197.04 PROTESTS AND COLLECTIONS.
   (A)   Liens.
      (1)   Liens may be filed in the Office of the Clerk of the County
Commission of Brooke or Hancock County as determined by location of the subject
property on real property located within municipal corporation limits for
unpaid and delinquent fire and police fees or charges, or for any other fee or
charge for which a lien may be authorized by the provisions of W.V. Code § 8-
13-13(d). Before any lien is filed, the Finance Director shall give the
property owner written notice, by certified mail return receipt requested, that
the city will file a lien unless the amount of the delinquency stated in the
notice is paid in full by the date stated. The date stated in the notice of
lien shall be no less than 90 days from the date the notice is mailed.
      (2)   The amount of the delinquency stated in the notice of lien shall
become final and conclusive and not subject to administrative or judicial
review unless the property owner takes one of the following steps:
         (a)   The property owner remits to the city the total amount of the
delinquency stated in the notice of lien. The timely payment of the amount of
the delinquency stated in the notice of lien does not prohibit the property
owner from filing a petition for review.
         (b)   The property owner timely files a petition for review of the
notice of lien requesting an administrative hearing as hereinafter set forth.
   (B)   Administrative review procedure. The property owner may file a
petition for review of the notice of lien requesting an administrative hearing
before the Judge of the Municipal Court. The petition for review must be filed
with the Municipal Court Clerk within 30 days of the date of the mailing of the
notice of lien. If the thirtieth day shall fall on a Saturday, Sunday or legal
holiday, the filing period shall be extended to the next regular business day.
The petition for review must be in writing and verified under oath by the
property owner. The petition for review must set forth with particularity the
items of the notice objected to or contested. The petition for review must
further state the reasons for each objection or contested fact. Fairness and
equity shall not be issues. The petition for review must state an address of
the property owner for purposes of service of all papers and hearing notices.
The petition for review must set out a copy of the notice or have a copy of the
notice of lien attached.
      (1)   Upon the timely filing of a petition for review, the Municipal
Court Clerk shall assign the petition for review a case number.
      (2)   The property owner at the time of filing the petition for review
must serve a copy of the petition for review upon the Finance Director.
      (3)   The Finance Director shall have ten days from the date of receipt
of the petition for review to file an answer with the Municipal Court Clerk
stating the nature of the case, the facts relied upon by the Finance Director
and an answer to each question presented for review. The Finance Director shall
serve a copy of the answer upon the property owner.
      (4)   Upon receipt of the answer, the Municipal Court Clerk shall assign
a time and place for an administrative hearing before the Judge of the
Municipal Court and shall provide written notice of the hearing to the Finance
Director and to the property owner at the address provided in the petition for
review.
      (5)   The administrative hearing before the Judge of the Municipal Court
is heard de novo, however, fairness and equity shall not be issues. The burden
of proof shall be on the property owner. The decisions of the Judge of the
Municipal Court shall be in writing and contain a statement of findings of
material fact and conclusions of law. The Judge of the Municipal Court has
authority to affirm, reverse, modify, or vacate the decision to record a
proposed lien. All decisions of the Judge of the Municipal Court must be issued
within a reasonable time, not to exceed 30 days from the close of the hearing.
Unless a timely appeal is taken to the Circuit Court with jurisdiction over the
subject property, the administrative decision of the Judge of the Municipal
Court shall be final and conclusive and not subject to additional review.
   (C)   Appeal to Circuit Court. Either the property owner or the Finance
Director may appeal the decision of the Municipal Court to the Circuit Court of
Brooke or Hancock County, West Virginia within 30 days of the date of mailing
of the notice of final decision. In addition to filing a petition for appeal
with the Circuit Court, a copy of the petition must be filed with the Municipal
Court Clerk and served on all parties appearing before the Judge of the
Municipal Court. Upon notice of appeal the Municipal Court Clerk shall transmit
the entire record of the proceeding to the Clerk of the Circuit Court. The
Circuit Court shall make a decision on the record below. New testimony may only
be taken in cases of an alleged irregularity in procedure. The Circuit Court
may allow oral argument and may require written briefs.
   (D)   General provisions.
      (1)   No user fee, collection cost, legal fees, interest or related costs
shall be subject to challenge greater than five years after the earlier of the
date of billing or the date of service.
      (2)   Upon the expiration of 90 days from the date stated in the notice
of lien and upon entry of a favorable final order by the Judge of the Municipal
Court, notwithstanding any appeal to the Circuit Court, the Finance Director
may record an appropriate lien unless a stay of the recordation of said lien is
entered by the Circuit Court.
      (3)   All time limitations provided for herein are jurisdictional and
exclusive.
(Ord. 1354, passed 9-9-02; Am. Ord. 2187, passed 4-11-22)
§ 197.05 POLICE AND FIRE SERVICE FEE APPEALS BOARD.
   There shall be established a Police and Fire Service Fee Appeals Board
consisting of three members, one a Councilman appointed by the Mayor, one shall
be the Fire Chief or Police Chief and the third shall be a resident of the city
appointed by Council. They shall serve at the will and pleasure of Council. Any
vacancy for whatever cause shall be filled by an appointment made by the
official that appointed the individual who is no longer on the Board.
(Ord. 1354, passed 9-9-02)

ARTICLE 301: ENFORCEMENT; IMPOUNDING
§ 301.01 ENFORCEMENT; DIRECTION OF TRAFFIC.
   It shall be the duty of the Police Department to enforce the provisions of
this traffic code. Officers of the Police Department are hereby authorized to
direct all traffic, either in person or by means of a visible or audible
signal, in conformance with the provisions of this traffic code; provided,
however, that in the event of fire or any other emergency or to expedite
traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the Police or Fire Department may
direct traffic, as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of
this traffic code.
('71 Code, § 301.01)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to regulate traffic by police officers, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-8
(2)
§ 301.02 FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH LAWFUL ORDER.
   No person shall refuse or fail to comply with any lawful order, signal or
direction of a police officer.
('71 Code, § 301.02)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-3(c)
   Obedience to state traffic law required, see W. V. Code Article 17C-2
§ 301.03 TRAFFIC VIOLATION TAGS GENERALLY.
   The Chief of the Police Department is hereby authorized and directed to
supply police officers with tags which shall be used for the purpose of giving
due notice to owners, chauffeurs and drivers of automobiles and other vehicles
where there are any violations of the traffic laws and rules of the Police
Department, that such owner shall appear before the judge of the Police Court
of the city, designating the date and time thereof; provided, however, that
this provision shall not interfere with the rights of the policeman to arrest
on view for crimes and misdemeanors.
('71 Code, § 301.03)
§ 301.04 IMPOUNDING OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLE.
   Any vehicle parked upon a public street of the city at a place, in a manner
or for a length of time prohibited by an ordinance of the city is, if
unoccupied, hereby declared to be an obstruction on such public street and a
public nuisance, and any police officer of the city, or duly authorized person,
is hereby authorized to cause the same to be removed and impounded. In addition
to the fine provided for such prohibited parking, the duly identified owner of
the vehicle will be required to pay any and all costs incurred in abating the
nuisance before the vehicle will be surrendered to such owner.
('71 Code, § 301.04) (Ord. 123, passed 12-7-59)
§ 301.05 ARREST WARRANT; SETTING BOND.
   Either the Chief of Police, the Captain of Police or the Lieutenant of
Police who issues an arrest warrant for the municipal offense of driving while
under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drugs shall also perform
the duties of magistrate, including the setting of bond, within the meaning of
W. V. Code § 17C-19-3.
('71 Code, § 301.05) (Ord. 398, passed 3-10-75)
§ 301.06 REGISTRATION AND TITLE.
   (A)   Every owner of a motor vehicle, trailer or other vehicle shall, within
30 days after taking up residence in the state, apply to the Department of
Motor Vehicles and obtain registration and title for the vehicle.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section, there is a rebuttable presumption
that a natural person is a resident of this state if any of the following
elements exist, including, but not limited to:
      (1)   The person is registered to vote in this state.
      (2)   The person enrolls the person’s child to be educated in a public
elementary or secondary school in this state.
      (3)   The person is receiving public assistance from this state.
      (4)   The person resides or has continuously remained in this state for a
period exceeding 30 days except for infrequent or brief absences.
      (5)   The person has accepted employment or engages in any trade,
profession, or occupation within this state, except that this does not include
a person who is commuting from the person’s residence in another state or whose
employment is seasonal or temporary, not exceeding 90 days.
      (6)   The person has filed for a homestead tax exemption on property in
this state.
      (7)   The person has contracted to receive utility service at a
residential location within the state.
   (C)   RESIDENT does not include a person who is attending a college,
university or other educational institution in this state, if the person has a
domicile in another state and has a valid operator’s license and vehicle
registration issued by the state of domicile. RESIDENT also does not include
members of the armed forces that are stationed in West Virginia, providing that
their vehicles are properly registered in their state of residence or a member
of the armed forces stationed in another state or country, providing their
vehicles are properly registered in that state or country.
   (D)   A corporation, association, partnership, company, or firm whose
principal place of business is located within this state is a resident of this
state.
   (E)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to vehicles registered
under proportional registration agreement.
   (F)   Penalty.
      (1)   It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to violate division (A) of
this section, and said violation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than
$500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both.
      (2)   Officers of the Weirton Police Department may issue a summons to
compel the attendance to court of the persons alleged to have violated division
(A) of this section and said summons shall have the same force and effect to
compel attendance as a warrant. They may also, in accordance with past
practice, issue warrants for the offense.
      (3)   In the event any part of this section shall be determined to be
unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder shall be
enforceable as written.
(Ord. 1450, passed 7-11-05)
ARTICLE 303: TRAFFIC COMMISSION
§ 303.01 CREATION; COMPOSITION; TERM OF MEMBERS.
   There is hereby created a Traffic Commission consisting of five persons, all
of whom must be qualified voters of the city. The five members shall be known
as Traffic Commissioners and shall be appointed by the Mayor, upon
recommendation of the City Manager and with the approval of Council. All such
appointments shall be made for periods of four years each by the appointing
power hereinbefore designated.
('71 Code, § 303.01)
§ 303.02 CHAIRMAN.
   On July 1 of each year, the Traffic Commissioners shall elect one of the
members of the Traffic Commission as Chairman, who shall serve for a period of
one year.
('71 Code, § 303.02)
§ 303.03 SECRETARY.
   The City Clerk shall be the Secretary of the Traffic Commission and he shall
act as its Secretary and perform or supervise the administrative work and shall
perform such other functions or duties as may be required of him by the Traffic
Commission.
('71 Code, § 303.03)
§ 303.04 QUORUM.
   Three members of the Traffic Commission shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business and a vote of three members of the Traffic Commission
shall control the actions of such Commission.
('71 Code, § 303.04)
§ 303.05 STUDIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS; ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
   The Traffic Commission shall study traffic problems of the city and shall
make such recommendations and reports to Council as may be necessary. The
Traffic Commission shall also discharge such duties as are authorized or
directed by this article.
('71 Code, § 303.05)
§ 303.06 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided, it shall be the duty of the Traffic
Commission, whenever authorized and directed by an order of Council, to erect
and place, or cause to be erected and placed, proper signs and markers or other
traffic warning devices or traffic control devices of any kind indicating
limited or prohibited parking, angle parking, parking of official vehicles,
parking of public service vehicles, one-way streets, restricted speed areas,
through or arterial streets, stop streets, U-turns, hazardous intersections,
turning at intersections, safety zones, play streets, school zones, hospital
zones, loading and unloading zones, quiet zones, traffic control signals
exhibiting colored lights or the words “go,” “caution” or “stop” and other
signs, markers or devices indicating the place and manner of operating or
parking vehicles within the corporate limits of the city.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Commission, whenever authorized
and directed by an order of Council, to mark off or cause to be marked off bus
stop stops and to erect or cause to be erected signs prohibiting the parking of
vehicles in such bus stops. The Traffic Commission shall mark off or cause to
be marked off stands for busses and erect or cause to be erected signs
prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than busses in such stands.
   (C)   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Commission, whenever authorized
and directed by an order of Council, to mark off or cause to be marked off
taxicab stands for taxicabs and to erect or cause to be erected signs
prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than taxicabs in such stands.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Commission, whenever authorized
and directed by an order of Council, to erect or cause to be erected signs
indicating truck routes and the parking of vehicles of various weights and
sizes.
   (E)   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Commission, whenever authorized
and directed by an order of Council, to mark off or cause to be marked off
traffic lanes and parts of streets indicating the direction and flow of traffic
thereon.
   (F)   It shall be the duty of the Traffic Commission, whenever authorized
and directed by an order of Council, to erect or place or cause to be erected
or placed signs, markers or devices indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic.
   (G)   Except as otherwise provided, it shall be the duty of the Traffic
Commission, whenever authorized and directed by an order of Council, to erect
or cause to be erected all other signs, markers or devices on any street in the
city indicating the manner in which vehicles shall be operated or parked.
   (H)   The existence of such signs, markers or devices at any place within
the corporate limits of the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs,
markers or devices were erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of
this section.
   (I)   No person shall fail or refuse to comply with the direction indicated
on or by any sign, marker or device erected or placed in accordance with the
provisions of this section, when so placed or erected.
('71 Code, § 303.06)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to regulate parking of vehicles, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-8(1)
§ 303.07 STORAGE OF AUTOMOBILES ON STREETS.
   The Traffic Commission is hereby authorized to prohibit on any or all
streets, alleys and other public thoroughfares the storing of automobiles and
other vehicles.
('71 Code, § 303.07)
ARTICLE 305: TRAFFIC CONTROL MAP
§ 305.01 ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby adopted and established a Traffic Control Map for the city,
which Map shall show at all times current designations of:
   (A)   Through streets;
   (B)   Stop intersections;
   (C)   Yield right-of-way intersections;
   (D)   One-way streets and lanes;
   (E)   Traffic control signals;
   (F)   Truck routes in addition to designated state and federal highways; and
   (G)   No parking zones; and
   (H)   Speed reduction devices.
('71 Code, § 305.01) (Ord. 214, passed 10-27-69; Am. Ord. 2163, passed 8-9-21)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to establish no parking zones, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-8(1)
   Authority to designate one-way streets, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-8(4)
   Authority to designate through streets and stop intersections, see W. V.
Code § 17C-2-8(6)
   Authority to place traffic control devices, see W. V. Code § 17C-3-3
   Authority to establish truck routes, see W. V. Code § 17C-17-12
§ 305.02 DESIGNATION.
   The Traffic Control Map hereby adopted is designated “Traffic Control Map of
the City of Weirton” and shall bear such caption and the date of adoption or
enactment.
('71 Code, § 305.02) (Ord. 214, passed 10-27-69)
§ 305.03 MAINTENANCE AND LOCATION.
   The Traffic Control Map shall be currently maintained and kept in the City
Building.
('71 Code, § 305.03) (Ord. 214, passed 10-27-69)
§ 305.04 AMENDMENTS.
   Amendments to the Traffic Control Map shall be by ordinance enacted by
Council, and upon effective date of such ordinance and upon the erection of
proper signs and markings giving notice thereof, amendments shall be in full
force and effect. All amendments shall be immediately revealed on the official
Traffic Control Map by the traffic sergeant.
('71 Code, § 305.04) (Ord. 214, passed 10-27-69)
