ARTICLE 331: OPERATION
§ 331.01 ADOPTION OF STATE LAW.
   All of the provisions and requirements of West Virginia Code Chapters 17A,
17B, 17C and 17D, in regard to traffic regulations and laws of the road, and
all of the provisions and requirements of West Virginia Code Chapter 60A and
61, or amendments or additions thereto, as well as any future amendments or
additions thereto, insofar as such provisions and requirements can have
application within the city, are hereby adopted and made a part hereof,
provided that local regulations shall not be affected by the adoption of the
state law under this section. No person shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply
with the provisions and requirements adopted herein.
('71 Code, § 331.01) (Ord. 863, passed 2-8-88; Am. Ord. 1225, passed 7-13-98;
Am. Ord. 1390, passed 9-8-03; Am. Ord. 1425, passed 9-13-04; Am. Ord. 1445,
passed 5-9-05; Am. Ord. 1485, passed 6-12-06; Am. Ord. 1528, passed 6-28-07;
Am. Ord. 1581, passed 5-12-08; Am. Ord. 1657, passed 8-10-09; Am. Ord. 1686,
passed 8-9-10; Am. Ord. 1700, passed 8-8-11; Am. Ord. 1722, passed 7-9-12; Am.
Ord. 1761, passed 10-7-13) Penalty, see §
101.99
§ 331.02 DRIVING THROUGH PROCESSIONS.
   No operator of any vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a
funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion, provided that
such vehicles are conspicuously so designated. This provision shall not apply
at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or
police officers.
('71 Code, § 331.02)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 331.03 AVOIDING TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES.
   No person shall drive any vehicle through a service station, properties and
corner lots in order to avoid a traffic control device.
('71 Code, § 331.03) (Ord. 209, passed 3-10-69)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 331.04 DRIVING WITHIN SIDEWALK AREA.
   The operator of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area, except
at a permanent or temporary driveway.
('71 Code, § 331.04)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 331.05 OPERATION IN PUBLIC ALLEY.
   No person shall drive any vehicle in a public alley at a speed in excess of
15 miles per hour.
('71 Code, § 331.05) (Ord. 204, passed 10-21-68)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 331.06 USE OF SNOW TIRES; CHAINS.
   (A)   Between November 1 of each year and April 1 of the following year, all
motor vehicles using any public street, roadway or alleyway in the city shall
be equipped with snow tires or winter tires or chains designed to provide
improved traction on ice and snow.
   (B)   In the event that any motor vehicle impedes the flow of traffic or
impedes the use by any other motor vehicle, of any public street, roadway or
alleyway within the city because any such motor vehicle is not equipped as
provided herein, the driver of the motor vehicle is hereby declared to be
guilty of a misdemeanor.
('71 Code, § 331.06) (Ord. 270, passed 10-26-71)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 331.07 ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES AND UNLICENSED MOTOR VEHICLES.
   (A)   The riding, operation, or other use of all-terrain vehicles for
transportation or recreational purposes or motor vehicles which have not been
licensed for street use by the West Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles,
within or upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, parking lots, and any realty
owned, leased, or controlled by the city, or any of its boards, authorities, or
commissions within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited.
   (B)   Any violation of division (A) above shall constitute the commission of
a misdemeanor criminal offense, and the Police Department of the city is hereby
authorized and empowered to issue a citation and to charge any such person who
commits a violation of division (A) above. Any person convicted of a first
offense established hereunder shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than
$100. Any person convicted of a second or further offense established hereunder
shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $250.
   (C)   For the purpose of this code section, the term ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE
shall be as defined in W. V. Code § 17A-1-1(ii) and the term MOTOR VEHICLE
shall be as defined in W. V. Code § 17A-1-1(b).
   (D)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this code section, it shall not
be an offense for any person to lawfully ride or operate any such all-terrain
vehicle or unlicensed motor vehicle upon any private property or upon any
governmental-owned realty not owned or controlled by the city, or any of its
boards, authorities, or commissions located within the corporate limits of the
city.
   (E)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this code section, it shall not
be an offense for any person licensed to operate a motor vehicle within the
State of West Virginia to ride, operate or otherwise use an all-terrain vehicle
or unlicensed motor vehicle upon a designated parade route, when such person is
a duly registered and recognized participant in any such properly permitted
parade, provided that such all-terrain vehicle or unlicensed motor vehicle
riding or operation occurs in conjunction with said parade.
   (F)   The federal government, the State of West Virginia and its political
subdivisions are exempt from the prohibitions contained herein, when any such
all-terrain vehicle or unlicensed motorvehicle is used for government.
   (G)   Nothing contained within the code section is intended, nor shall be
construed so as to create or form the basis of any civil or administrative
liability whatsoever on the part of the city or any of its officers, officials,
employees, or agents, for any injury or damage resulting to any person as a
consequence of any action or inaction on the part of the city related in any
manner to the enforcement or non-enforcement of this code section by the city's
officers, officials, employees, or agents.
   (H)   The parent or guardian of any person not having attained the age of 18
years shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such minor to violate any
provision within this code section. Any such authorization or knowingly
permitting any such minor to violate the provisions of this code section shall
constitute a separate criminal violation hereof and shall subject such parent
or guardian to the criminal penalties set forth in this code section. The
citing of any parent or guardian pursuant to this division shall not be reason
to prohibit the police officer from also citing the driver of said all-terrain
vehicle or motor vehicle which has not been licensed by the West Virginia
Department of Motor Vehicles for street use.
   (I)   The provisions of this code section are severable, and in the event
any provision or part hereof shall be held invalid for any reason by any court
exercising competent jurisdiction, then such invalidity shall not be deemed to
affect or impair any of the other provisions of this code section not
specifically held to be invalid. It is hereby declared to be the intent of the
city that this code section would have been adopted if any such invalid
provision or part hereof had not been included herein.
   (J)   It is an absolute defense to an alleged violation of this section that
the driver at the time of arrest, was on his/her way to perform work with the
vehicle, the attachment to the vehicle of a snow plow, plow or a trailer, or
other device designed to perform work by moving snow or earth, or for hauling
materials, shall be prima facie evidence that this vehicle is performing work
or is being transported to or from a place of work.
(Ord. 1397, passed 10-14-03)
§ 331.08 SECURING OF TRUCK AND TRAILER LOADS.
   The following chart is hereby adopted as the standard for the number of
chains required to secure truck or trailer loads carried on our city streets,
and it is further ordained that trucks or trailers with loads secured by fewer
chains than provided on this chart are not securely fastened for the purposes
of determining whether a violation of W. V. Code § 17C-17-6 has occurred.

ARTICLE 351: PARKING GENERALLY
§ 351.01 PARKING IN ALLEY.
   No operator shall park a vehicle within a public alley less than 18 feet
wide.
('71 Code, § 351.01) (Ord. 204, passed 10-21-68)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.02 NIGHT PARKING ON MAIN STREET.
   No person shall park any vehicle on Main Street between the hours of 2:30
a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
('71 Code, § 351.02) (Ord. 225, passed 3-9-70)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.03 REPAIRING VEHICLES ON STREETS.
   Except in cases of accident or emergency when a vehicle cannot conveniently
be removed to a garage or other building where repairs can be made, no person
shall dismantle a vehicle or perform repairs thereto on the streets or alleys
of the city.
('71 Code, § 351.03)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.04 WASHING VEHICLES.
   No person shall wash any vehicle on any street, sidewalk, alley or public
way within the city.
('71 Code, § 351.04)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.05 CROSS PARKING.
   No person shall cross park an automobile or other vehicle on a two-way
street.
('71 Code, § 351.05)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.06 PARKING FOR ADVERTISEMENT.
   No person shall park on any street any vehicle for the primary purpose of
displaying advertising.
('71 Code, § 351.06)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.07 PRIVATE NO PARKING ZONES.
   Owners or occupants of any wholesale or retail mercantile establishment in a
building used primarily for business purposes, may make application to the
Traffic Commission for a “no parking” space in front of the business building.
The same privilege shall be extended to doctors, with respect to their homes
and offices, and to industrial firms in front of industrial plants and offices.
The Traffic Commission may, upon show of sufficient cause, establish a no
parking zone of not less than 18 feet in front of such business places, and
shall erect or cause to be erected no parking signs clearly indicating such
space. The Traffic Commission shall make suitable arrangements to provide
adequate parking for all funeral processions and temporary signs therefor. The
signs shall be uniform with all other no parking signs erected throughout the
city.
('71 Code, § 351.07)
§ 351.08 PARKING OF COMMERCIAL AND HEAVY VEHICLES.
   (A)   The parking of truck tractors, road tractors, trailers and
semitrailers on the public streets and alleyways of the city is hereby
prohibited.
   (B)   The definitions of truck tractors, road tractors, trailers and
semitrailers shall conform to those definitions set forth in W. V. Code Chapter
17A. The definition of trailers shall further include travel trailers,
motorhomes, certain camping trailers and recreational vehicles as defined in W.
V. Code § 17A-1-1(jj), (kk), (ll), and (nn).
   (C)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the reasonable
loading or unloading of any motor vehicle.
('71 Code, § 351.08) (Ord. 176, passed 6-7-65; Am. Ord. 2212, passed 10-23-23)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.09 RESERVED
§ 351.10 PARKING AUTO TRAILER ON STREET OVERNIGHT.
   (A)   Definitions.
      MOTOR HOME/RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. A motorized vehicle designed to provide
temporary living quarters.
      REFUSE TRAILER. Roll-off or construction trailers designed to transport
construction refuse to landfills.
      TRAILER. Every vehicle without motive of power designed to carry persons
or property and/or being drawn by a motor vehicle, including, but not limited
to, utility/equipment trailers, boat trailers, auto trailers, motorcycle
trailers and storage trailers.
      TRAVEL TRAILER. A trailer designed to provide temporary living quarters.
   (B)   No person shall park any trailer or travel trailer on any street in
the city.
   (C)   No person shall park a travel trailer or a motor home on any street in
the city overnight for the purpose of lodging.
   (D)   No person shall park a refuse trailer on any public street within the
city without a permit.
('71 Code, § 351.10) (Am. Ord. 1350, passed 8-12-02; Am. Ord. 2212, passed 10-
23-23)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.11 FIXED FINES FOR CERTAIN PARKING VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Any person upon whose automobile or other vehicle is placed a traffic
violation notice or tag or upon whom a traffic violation notice or tag is
served, charged with any of the parking violations set forth herein, may appear
before the Police Court Clerk between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m.,
within 24 hours of the time when such traffic violation notice or tag is so
placed upon the automobile or other vehicle or so served and, in that event, if
such person so desires, he may plead guilty to the charge and pay a fixed fine
in the amount hereinafter shown for the offense for which he is charged, as
follows:
Fire hydrant parking     $ 20
Improper parking         20
Red line parking         20
Yellow line parking      20
Loading zone violation   20
Double parking           20
Handicapped only parking 100
Fire lane parking        100
   (B)   In the event such procedure is followed, no additional costs will be
charged against the offender, provided, however, that in the discretion of the
Police Court Judge, a person committing any of such offenses more than twice in
any calendar year, may be fined up to $200 and imprisoned not more than 20
days, or both, and a person committing any of such offenses more than three
times in a calendar year, may be fined up to $500 or imprisoned not more than
30 days, or both. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to deprive a
person of his right to a trial in the Police Court of the city, if such trial
is desired; but, in such event, if the person is convicted of the offense, the
only limitation as to the penalty shall be that provided in §
101.99 of these codified ordinances and court costs shall be assessed as
provided in §
171.08.
('71 Code, § 351.11) (Ord. 596, passed 5-12-80; Am. Ord. 1172, passed 5-12-97)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.12 RESTRICTING PARKING ON THE MUNICIPAL PLAZA PARKING LOT.
   (A)   No vehicle shall be parked in the Municipal Plaza Parking Lot unless
the driver thereof works at, is transacting business at or is in attendance at
the Weirton Municipal Building, the Mary H. Weir Public Library, the station of
the Weirton Fire Department or the Millsop Community Center, including the
recreation field situated at the eastern perimeter of the parking lot. Any
vehicle parked in violation of the provisions of this section may be towed from
the lot and all costs of towing shall be assessed to the owner of the
improperly parked vehicle.
   (B)   This section shall be in effect Monday thru Friday.
('71 Code, § 351.12) (Ord. 732, passed 4-9-84)
Penalty, see § 351.99
§ 351.13 HANDICAPPED PARKING SPACE SPECIFICATIONS.
   To facilitate the enforcement of state laws regulating parking in
handicapped spaces, all handicapped accessible parking spaces within the city
will conform to the following:
   (A)   Each space will be marked by fluorescent paint;
   (B)   Each space will be at least 96 inches (2,440 mm) wide; and
   (C)   Each space will be so designated as reserved by a vertical sign
showing the symbol for handicapped parking.
(Ord. 1025, passed 6-7-93)
§ 351.14 PARKING PERMITS ON NORTH SIDE OF VIRGINIA AVENUE.
   The Municipal Court Clerk of the city is hereby authorized to issue not more
than 20 parking permits for a fee of $20 per permit to the Independent
Steelworkers Union (ISU) to permit parking without paying meter fees along the
north side of Virginia Avenue between the west side of Main Street and the east
side of Orchard Street. Said parking permits shall be renewable annually upon
the same terms and conditions as set forth hereinabove.
(Ord. 926, passed 9-10-90)
§ 351.15 PARKING TIME LIMIT.
   No person shall park a legally parked vehicle upon a public street or right-
of-way for a period not to exceed 72 hours. A notice of violation shall be
placed upon the vehicle. Any vehicle parked upon a public street of the city at
a place, in a manner or for a length of time prohibited by city ordinance, if
unoccupied, hereby declared to be an obstruction on such public street and a
public nuisance, and any police officer of the city, or duly authorized person,
is hereby authorized to cause the same to be removed and impounded. In addition
to the fine provided for such prohibited parking, the duly identified owner of
the vehicle will be required to pay any and all costs incurred in abating the
nuisance before the vehicle will be surrendered to such owner.
(Ord. 1375, passed 5-12-03)
§ 351.16 CONDITION OF PARKED VEHICLES.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon a public street or right-of-way that is
not in good working order or is not in a safe operating condition. Vehicles
shall have a current state tag and valid inspection sticker in place. Notice of
violations shall be placed upon the vehicle and penalties as outlined in §
301.04 shall apply.
(Ord. 1375, passed 5-12-03)
§ 351.17 PARKING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall park or place a “motor vehicle” or “other personal property”
within the grassy or otherwise unimproved area of any front or side yard.
(Ord. 2016, passed 1-9-17)
§ 351.18 NO PARKING ZONES AT STREET INTERSECTIONS.
   A standard length for a no parking area shall be established at all street
intersections for a distance of 15 feet in both directions of the corner of the
intersection unless another specific City of Weirton ordinance or West Virginia
State Code regulation establishes a specific length for a no parking area at
the intersection.
(Ord. 2135, passed 11-9-20)
§ 351.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates §
351.08 shall be fined not more than $100 or imprisoned not more than 30 days,
or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a continuing violation occurs. All other violations shall be punished
according to §
101.99.
('71 Code, § 351.99) (Ord. 176, passed 6-7-65)
ARTICLE 353: CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT COURTESY PARKING
§ 353.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF COURTESY PARKING ZONES.
   The following described streets in the city are hereby designated and
established as courtesy parking zones: on Main Street from the intersection of
Cove Road, north to the intersection of Virginia Avenue; on West Street from
the intersection of Purdy Lane, north to the intersection of Virginia Avenue;
on Lee Avenue, from the west terminus of the Lee Avenue Bridge, west to the
intersection of West Street; on Ferguson Avenue, from the intersection of Tin
Mill Alley, west to the intersection of West Street; on Virginia Avenue, from
the intersection of Main Street, west to the intersection of West Street; and
any additional streets and areas as designated by order of Council.
('71 Code, § 353.01) (Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
§ 353.02 INSTALLATION, MAINTENANCE AND REGULATION.
   The City Manager shall provide for the installation of signs designating
parking areas, provide for the delineation of parking stalls by curb and/or
street marking lines, and the regulation and maintenance thereof.
('71 Code, § 353.02) (Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
§ 353.03 COURTESY PARKING HOURS.
   No vehicle shall be parked in any courtesy parking stall for a period longer
than two hours at any one time. Courtesy parking shall be available from 8:00
a.m. to 6:00 p.m. during each weekday and Saturdays. Parking time restrictions
shall not be operative or effective on Sundays or on the following holidays:
New Year’s Day, Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas
Day.
('71 Code, § 353.05) (Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
Penalty, see § 353.99
§ 353.04 METHOD OF PARKING; UNLAWFUL PARKING.
   (A)   When any vehicle is parked in a courtesy parking stall, the owner or
operator of such motor vehicle shall park within the area designated at the
curb and/or street marking lines, as indicated for parallel or diagonal
parking. No person shall fail to park within such designated area.
   (B)   Such parking space may then be used by such vehicle during the legal
parking limit and such vehicle shall be considered unlawfully parked if it
remains beyond the legal parking limit. No person shall cause or permit any
vehicle registered in his name to be unlawfully parked as set forth in this
section.
('71 Code, § 353.06) (Ord. 397, passed 2-26-75; Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
Penalty, see § 353.99
§ 353.05 CITATION TAGS; PROCEDURE FOR VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   The Police Chief is hereby authorized and directed to supply police
officers with citation tags for the purpose of giving notice to persons
violating any of the provisions of this article. Such notice may be given by
delivering such tags to the violator or by affixing it to the vehicle by means
of which the violation occurred. Such citation tag shall direct the violator to
appear and to present such tag at a designated place on or before a date and
hour specified thereon. Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge
the power of a police officer to arrest any violator and take him into custody.
   (B)   Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped
in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this article, the officer
finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other
information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall
conspicuously affix to such vehicle, a notice in writing on a form provided by
the city for the driver to answer to the charge against him within three days
and at the time and place specified in the notice. The officer shall deliver
copies of such notices to the officer in charge.
('71 Code, § 353.11) (Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
§ 353.06 FIXED FINE FOR OVERTIME PARKING.
   Any person upon whose automobile or other vehicle is placed a violation
notice or tag, charging such person with an overtime parking violation, may
appear before the Police Court Clerk and, in that event if such person so
desires, may plead guilty to the charge and pay a fixed fine in the amount of
$20 for the offense of overtime parking. If the fine(s) is not paid within 30
days of violation, a warrant shall be issued subjecting the violator to the
provisions of §
353.99.
('71 Code, § 353.12) (Ord. 595, passed 5-12-80; Am. Ord. 1239, passed 11-9-98;
Am. Ord. 1297, passed 10-10-00; Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
Penalty, see § 353.99
§ 353.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates, permits or allows anyone to violate §§
353.03 and
353.04 shall, upon conviction, be fined and shall pay a fixed penalty for each
violation as provided in §
353.06. If any person has committed three such violations within the period of
one year, then such fixed penalty provisions shall not apply and the penalty
shall be that set forth in division (B) herein.
   (B)   Whoever commits three overtime parking violations within one year or
fails to answer to pay the fixed fine provided in §
353.06, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than $100 or be imprisoned for
not more than 30 days.
('71 Code, § 353.99) (Am. Ord. 1454, passed 9-12-05)
ARTICLE 355: RESIDENTIAL DISABILITY PARKING SPACES
§ 355.01 PURPOSE.
   (A)   Short title. This article and ordinances supplemental and amendatory
to it shall be known and may be cited as “Residential Disability Parking Space
Ordinance.”
   (B)   Purpose. This article is enacted for the purpose of establishing an
application process for residential disability parking spaces (hereinafter
referred to as “RDPS”) within public rights-of-way within the corporate
municipal limits of the city, and to authorize within the scope and framework
of this article the procedures by which the Traffic Commission may review
applications for RDPS and forward recommendations for Council action in a
consistent, uniform, non-discriminatory manner.
   (C)   Authority. This article is an action of the Common Council to address
the issuance, maintenance, and term of RDPS within the city’s corporate
municipal limits.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   For the purpose of this article, certain terms and words used herein
shall be interpreted or defined as follows:
      (1)   Words used in the present tense shall include the future.
      (2)   Words used in the singular shall include the plural. Words used in
the plural shall include the singular.
      (3)   The word “person” includes a profit or non-profit corporation,
company, partnership, individual or an association of individuals.
      (4)   The word “lot” includes the words “plot” or “parcel.”
      (5)   The terms “shall” and “will” are always mandatory.
      (6)   The word “may” is permissive.
      (7)   The words “used” or “occupied” as applied to any land or building
shall be construed to include the words “intended,” “arranged” or “designed” to
be used or occupied.
      (8)   The word “building” includes the word “structure.”
      (9)   Unless otherwise specified, all distances shall be measured
horizontally.
      (10)   The masculine shall include the feminine.
   (B)   For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALLEY. A public service way providing a secondary means of public access to
abutting property and not intended for general traffic circulation.
   AREA, BUILDING. The total of the exterior areas taken on a horizontal plain
at the main floor of the principal building and all accessory buildings,
exclusive of uncovered porches, terraces, and steps.
   AREA, LOT. The total area within the lot lines.
   BUILDING. Any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls and
intended for the shelter, housing or enclosure of any individual, animal,
process, equipment, goods or materials of any kind or to and from said real
estate; location of all adjacent or adjoining streets; all of which presents a
unified or organized four arrangement of streets, lots, buildings and public
and service facilities and other improvements such as landscape development,
and public parking areas, all of which shall have a functional relationship to
the real estate comprising the planned development and to the use of properties
immediately adjacent thereto.
   DISABILITY. A physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one
or more major life activities or a record of such impairment or being regarded
as having such an impairment. This term does not include the illegal use of or
addiction to a controlled substance.
   DWELLING. A building or portion thereof, used primarily as a place of abode
for one or more human beings, but not including hotels, motels, lodging or
boarding houses, or tourist homes as defined in this article.
   DWELLING TYPE.
      (1)   ATTACHED. A one-family dwelling attached to two or more one-family
dwellings by common vertical walls and also referred to as row houses or
townhouses.
      (2)   MOBILE HOME. A transportable, factory-built home, designed to be
used as a year-round residential dwelling and built prior to the enactment of
the Federal Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974,
which became effective June 15, 1976.
      (3)   MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING UNITS. Any building or structure having more
than two.
      (4)   SINGLE-FAMILY DETACHED. A dwelling unit with is designed for and
occupied by not more than one family and surrounded by open space or yards.
      (5)   SINGLE-FAMILY SEMI-DETACHED. Two dwelling units accommodating two
families which are attached side by side through the use of adjoining walls,
and having one side yard adjacent to each dwelling unit.
      (6)   TWO-FAMILY DETACHED. Two dwelling units accommodating four
families, two units of which are located directly over the other two units. A
combination of both the single-family semi-detached and the two-family detached
structures.
   DWELLING UNIT. Any building or portion thereof which is designed and used
exclusively for residential purposes of one family, and includes complete
kitchen and bathroom facilities.
   FAMILY. One or more persons occupying a dwelling unit and living as a
single, nonprofit housekeeping unit; provided that a group of four or more
persons who are not within the second degree of kinship shall not be deemed to
constitute a family. Notwithstanding the definition in the preceding sentence,
a family shall be deemed to include four or more persons occupying a dwelling
unit and living as a single, nonprofit housekeeping unit, if said occupants are
disabled persons as defined in this article (See DISABILITY).
   FENCE. An artificially constructed barrier of any material or combination of
materials erected to enclose or screen areas of land.
   FRONTAGE. That side of a lot abutting on a street; the front lot line.
   GARAGE, PRIVATE. An enclosed building for the storage of one or more motor
vehicles. No business, occupation or service shall be conducted in a private
garage that is accessory to a dwelling, except as may be allowed as a home
occupation.
   GRADE. The degree of rise or descent of a sloping surface.
   GRADE, ESTABLISHING. The elevation of the centerline of the streets as
officially established by the municipal authorities.
   GRADE, FINISHED. The completed surfaces of lawns, walks, and roads brought
to grades as shown on official plans or designs relating thereto.
   GROUP RESIDENTIAL FACILITY. A facility which provides residential services
and supervision for individuals who are listed as having a disability or is
occupied as a residence by individuals who are disabled.
   HOME OCCUPATION. An occupation or profession carried on in a residential
dwelling, or accessory structure thereto, and clearly incidental and secondary
to the residential use of such dwelling or structure.
      (1)   HOME OCCUPATION, CATEGORY I. A home occupation employing the owners
plus no more than one non-resident employee, agent, or subcontractor and which
is not open to the general public and which does not require a sign, parking or
other exterior indicia of a home occupation.
      (2)   HOME OCCUPATION, CATEGORY II. A home occupation employing the
owners plus no more than two non-resident employees, agents, or subcontractors,
and which may be open to the general public.
   INSTITUTIONAL USE. A non-profit or quasi-public use or institution such as a
church, library, public or private school, hospital, or municipally owned or
operated building, structure or land used for public purpose.
   LOADING SPACE. An off street space or berth used for the loading or
unloading of commercial vehicles.
   LOT. A designated parcel, tract or area of land established by a plat,
subdivision or as otherwise permitted by law and to be used, developed or built
upon as a unit.
   LOT AREA. The total area within the lot lines of a lot, excluding any street
rights-of-way.
   LOT, CORNER. A lot or parcel of land abutting upon two or more streets at
their intersection, or upon two parts of the same street forming an interior
angle of less than 135 degrees.
   LOT COVERAGE. The area of a site covered by buildings or roofed area
excluding allowed projecting eaves, balconies, and similar features.
   LOT DEPTH. The average horizontal distance between the front and rear lot
lines. For lots where the front and rear lot lines are not parallel, the lot
depth should be measured by drawing lines from the front to rear lot lines, at
right angles to the front lot line, every ten feet and averaging the length of
these lines.
   LOT, FLAG. A lot not fronting on or abutting a public road and where access
to the public road is a narrow, private right-of-way.
   LOT, FRONTAGE. The length of the front lot line measured at the street
right-of-way line.
   LOT, INTERIOR. A lot other than a corner lot or through lot.
   LOT LINE. A line of record bounding a lot which divides one lot from another
lot or from a public or private street or any other public space.
   LOT LINE, FRONT. The lot line separating a lot from a street right-of-way. A
corner or through lot shall have two front lot lines.
   LOT LINE, REAR. The lot line opposite and most distant from the front lot
line; or in the case of triangular or otherwise irregularly shaped lots, a line
ten feet in length entirely within the lot, parallel to and at a maximum
distance from the front lot line.
   LOT LINE, SIDE. Any lot line other than a front or rear lot line.
   LOT, MINIMUM AREA OF. The smallest lot area established by the zoning
ordinance on which a use or structure may be located in a particular district.
   LOT OF RECORD. A lot which exists as shown or described on a plat or deed
which is recorded in the Office of the Clerk of the County Court of either
Brooke or Hancock County.
   LOT, REVERSE FRONTAGE. A through lot which is not accessible from one of the
parallel or non-intersecting streets upon which it fronts.
   LOT, THROUGH. A lot which fronts upon two parallel streets, or which fronts
upon two streets which do not intersect at the boundaries of the lot.
   LOT WIDTH. The horizontal distance between the side lines of a lot measured
at right angles to its depth along a straight line parallel to the front lot
line at the minimum required building setback line.
   LOWEST FLOOR. The lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including
basement). An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, usable solely for
parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a
basement area is not considered a building’s lowest floor; provided, that such
enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of the
applicable non-elevation design requirements of this article.
   MEDICAL OFFICE. A use involving the treatment and examination of patients by
state-licensed physicians or dentists; provided that no patients shall be kept
overnight on the premises. This use may involve the testing of tissue, blood or
other human materials for medical or dental purposes.
   NURSING HOME. A facility licensed by the state for the housing and
intermediate or fully-skilled nursing care of three or more persons.
   OFFICE. A room or group of rooms used for conducting the affairs of a
business, profession, service, industry, or government.
   OFFICE BUILDING. A building used primarily for conducting the affairs of a
business, profession, service, industry, or government, or like activity, that
may include ancillary services for office workers, such as a restaurant, coffee
shop, newspaper or candy stand.
   OWNER. The duly authorized agent, attorney, purchaser, devisee, fiduciary or
any person having vested or equitable interest in the lot in question.
   PARKING AREA. Any public or private land area designed and used for parking
motor vehicles including parking lots, garages, private driveways and legally
designated area of public streets.
   PARKING AREA, PRIVATE. A parking area for the private use of the owners or
occupants of the lot on which the parking area is located.
   PARKING AREA, PUBLIC. A parking area available to the public, with or
without compensation or used to accommodate clients, customers, or employees.
   PARKING BAY. The parking module consisting of one or two rows of parking
spaces and the aisle from which motor vehicles enter and leave the spaces.
   PARKING LOT. An off street, ground level area, usually surfaced and
improved, for the temporary storage of motor vehicles.
   PARKING SPACE. A space for the parking of a motor vehicle within a public
parking area.
   PERSON. Any individual or group of individuals, corporation, partnership,
association or other entity, including state and local governments and
agencies.
   PERSONAL CARE HOME. A facility licensed or registered by the state for the
housing and intermediate care of three or fewer persons.
   PERSONAL SERVICE. An establishment that provides a service oriented to
personal needs of the general public and which does not involve primarily
retail or wholesale sales or service to businesses. Personal services include
barber and beauty shops, massage therapy, photography studios, shoe repair
shops, household appliance repair shops, dry cleaning and laundry, and other
similar establishments.
   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. A vehicle which is:
      (1)   Built on a single chassis;
      (2)   Four hundred square feet or less when measured at the largest
horizontal projection;
      (3)   Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light
duty truck;
      (4)   Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling, but as
temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use.
   SCHOOL. A facility that provides a curriculum of elementary and secondary
academic instruction, including kindergartens, elementary schools, middle
schools, and high schools.
   SHELTER/EMERGENCY. A facility whose general purpose is to provide temporary
food, clothing, or sleeping arrangements to persons, families, or parts of
families on a temporary occupancy who are homeless or displaced due to urgent
events, such as fire, flood, or incidents of domestic violence. The shelter
shall have appropriate supervisory personnel. The maximum occupancy for an
emergency shelter is 20 persons. Such facility must meet all applicable
standards of the Department of Health, State Fire Marshal, and any other
federal, state, county, or city agency which has regulatory power over the said
facility.
   SHELTER/MISSION. A facility whose general purpose is to provide temporary
food, clothing or sleeping arrangements to persons, families, or parts of
families on a temporary occupancy who are homeless or displaced. Short term
counseling during stay may also be provided. The shelter shall have appropriate
supervisory personnel. Such facility must meet all applicable standards of the
Department of Health, State Fire Marshal, and any other federal, state, county,
or city agency which has regulatory power over the said facility.
   SIGN. Any object, device, display, or structure, or part thereof, situated
outdoors or indoors, which is used to advertise, identify, display, direct or
attract attention to an object, person, institution, organization, business,
product, service, event or location by any means, including words, letters,
figures, design, symbols, fixtures, colors, illumination or projected images
excluding national or state flags, window displays, graffiti, athletic
scoreboards, or the official announcements or signs of government.
   STREET. Includes street, avenue, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, parkway,
lane, alley, viaduct, and any other ways used or intended to be used by
vehicular traffic or pedestrians whether public or private.
   TRAILER (TRAVEL AND RELATED CAMPING AND RECREATIONAL EQUIPMENT). Includes
travel trailers, pick-up coaches, motorized homes, and recreational equipment
as follows:
      (1)   TRAVEL TRAILER. A portable structure built on a chassis, designed
to be towed and used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and
vacation purposes, and permanently identified as a travel trailer by the
manufacturer of the trailer.
      (2)   MOTORIZED HOME OR RECREATION VEHICLE. A portable dwelling designed
and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle.
      (3)   BOAT. A vessel designed to travel on water.
   YARD. An open space that lies between the principal or accessory building or
buildings and the nearest lot line. Such yard is unoccupied and unobstructed
from the ground upward except as may be specifically provided in the Zoning
Ordinance.
   YARD DEPTH. The shortest distance between a lot line and a yard line.
   YARD, FRONT. Space extending the full width of the lot between any building
and the front lot line, and measured perpendicular to the building at the
closest point to the front lot line. Such front yard is unoccupied and
unobstructed from the ground upward, other than by steps, walks, terraces,
driveways, lamp posts, and similar appurtenances. Covered porches whether
enclosed or unenclosed, shall be considered as part of the main building and
shall not project into a required front yard.
   YARD LINE. A line drawn parallel to a lot line at a distance there from
equal to the depth of the required yard.
   YARD, REAR. A space extending across the full width of the lot between the
principal building and the rear lot line, and measured perpendicular to the
building to, the closest point of the rear lot line. Such rear yard is
unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward other than by accessory
buildings which do not occupy more than 30% of the required space, and steps,
walks, terraces, driveways, lamp posts, and similar structures.
   YARD, REQUIRED. The open space between the lot line and the buildable area
within which no structure shall be located except as provided in the Zoning
Ordinance.
   YARD, SIDE. A space extending from the front yard to the rear yard between
the principal building and the side lot line measured perpendicular from the
side lot line to the closest point of the principal building. Such space is
unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward other than by architectural
appurtenances projecting not more than 24 inches from the building, or open or
lattice-enclosed fire escapes or fireproof outside stairways projecting not
more than four feet and certain accessory uses in accordance with the
provisions of this article.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.03 EXCLUSIONS.
   The following situations will be excluded for RDPS consideration: group
residential facilities, home occupied businesses, institutional not-for-profit
businesses conducted within residential localities, medical offices, nursing
home facilities, any shelter/mission, any school, nor in conjunction with any
travel trailer which may be utilized as a permanent or temporary dwelling.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.04 ISSUANCE PROCESS.
   The Traffic Commission is the sole entity through which application for RDPS
is made. Applications for same are reviewed with recommendations to Council for
the establishment of RDPS within the rights-of-way of the corporate municipal
boundaries of Weirton. RDPS will be approved on a yearly basis. It will be the
responsibility of the disabled person seeking an RDPS to re-apply every two
years. This application renewal process will occur between January 1 and
January 15 of each calendar year. The initial application fee is a
nonrefundable $40, with no fees due for re-application.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.05 REQUIRED DOCUMENTATION.
   Applicants for RDPS must complete a City of Weirton Traffic Commission RDPS
application form. It must be accompanied by a copy of the “Physically Disabled
State of West Virginia Registration Card” authorizing the disability placard or
license plate disabled designation. A copy of a valid West Virginia operator’s
license issued to the disability applicant, proof of ownership of vehicle
appropriately licensed in the State of West Virginia and meeting all current
vehicular certifications and requirements, and a copy of the certificate of
insurance with current policy information must also be produced.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.06 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   The Traffic Commission will conduct an on-site inspection in
connection with each application tendered for RDPS consideration. The on-site
inspection will review standards set forth below:
      (1)   Applicant must be a resident of the city utilizing the application
dwelling location as their primary residence.
      (2)   The request for RDPS must allow for issuance of a space allocation
which is contiguous to the property. If space is not contiguous, adjacent
property owners must be provided notice in order that their comments regarding
issuance may be incorporated into the decision-making process.
      (3)   RDPS should only be issued if off street parking cannot be created.
If the applicant has a driveway in front or in rear of the residence where no
other impediments exist, the request may be denied. If the applicant has an
integral garage attached to the residence, the application may be denied. If
the applicant has off street parking available or can create same, the
application may be denied. If the situation displays significant obstruction
consistent with ADA regulations, then the application may be approved.
   (B)   The Traffic Commission may also take into consideration other issues
regarding issuance not listed above. If after review by the Traffic Commission
an applicant is to be awarded an RDPS, the Traffic Commission under its normal
operating scenario will send the recommendation for enactment of Ordinance
establishing the RDPS, consistent with the traffic control map and procedures
already established by the Common Council.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
§ 355.07 APPLICABILITY AND TERM OF ISSUANCE.
   RDPS spaces are for the exclusive use of the person who has applied for,
paid for, and received Traffic Commission approval for such a space. Permits
for spaces will be allocated on every two years, at which time space will be
removed if re-application and re-certification is not completed by the
individual with the disability. The Department of Public Works will install the
signs and establish RDPS consistent with specifications set forth in Ordinance
1025 enacted by the Common Council on June 7, 1993. Signage must display the
placard number and/or the disabled plate number of the disabled person’s
vehicle for their exclusive use. Applicants must immediately notify the Traffic
Commission when spaces are no longer needed during the course of the year prior
to any certification period established herein.
(Ord. 1309, passed 1-8-01)
ARTICLE 357: PARKING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS
§ 357.01 RESIDENTS REQUIRING PARKING PERMITS.
   (A)   All of Orchard Street from the 3000 block to the end of the 3700 block
of Orchard Street.
   (B)   3400 block of Zeta Street.
   (C)   Washington Street.
   (D)   West side of Cross Street from its intersection with School Street to
its intersection with Church Street.
   (E)   West side of Preston Avenue from the alley south to the school
property.
   (F)   3900 block of Grant Street between Orr Street and Heaslett Avenue.
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21; Ord. 2243, passed 4-7-25; Ord. 2246, passed 6-9-
25)
§ 357.02 NUMBER OF PERMITS AUTHORIZED.
   (A)   Two primary permits (one per vehicle not to exceed two vehicles).
   (B)   One visitor permit.
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21; Ord. 2246, passed 6-9-25)
§ 357.03 WHAT IS NEEDED TO OBTAIN PARKING PERMIT.
   (A)   In order to obtain a residential parking permit, the resident must
fill out an application for the number of permits sought. In addition to the
resident's name and address, the applicant must provide the make, model, color,
license number and vehicle identification number for the vehicles sought to be
permitted.
   (B)   To obtain a permit, the resident must show a valid West Virginia
driver's license, current West Virginia registration and valid proof of
insurance. All documents must have the address for which the permit is sought.
In the case of a company-owned or leased vehicle, the resident must provide
verification from the owner that the vehicle is assigned to the resident. Each
permit is only valid for the specifically identified vehicle. If in the process
of moving, the resident must have a utility bill showing a Weirton address.
   (C)   If a resident changes vehicles, the old permit must be surrendered
prior to receipt of a new permit. The resident must provide the information as
set forth in divisions (A) and (B) above for the new vehicles prior to receipt
of the new permit.
   (D)   Each residential unit may receive one visitor permit.
   (E)   A visitor permit may not be used for any person and/or vehicle that is
not visiting the residence for which the permit was issued. Violation of said
visitor permit will result in cancellation of the visitor permit.
   (F)   The permit must be prominently displayed in the vehicle. Failure to
properly display the permit may result in the issuance of a citation.
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21; Ord. 2246, passed 6-9-25)
§ 357.04 COST PER PERMIT.
   (A)   $5.00 per permit annually.
   (B)   A resident who owns and occupies their home may apply for a multi-year
permit(s) as follows:
      (1)   $22.00 per permit for five years.
      (2)   Permits are non-transferable. In the event a resident sells their
home, the permit(s) must be relinquished back to the city. No refunds will be
issued for any unused time remaining on the permit(s).
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21; Ord. 2246, passed 6-9-25)
§ 357.05 EXPIRATION; RENEWAL.
   Permits are valid for one year beginning July 1 and ending June 30 of each
year. All permits must be renewed prior to July 1 of each year.
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21)
§ 357.06 VISITOR PERMITS.
   (A)   To allow those holding existing parking permits to obtain one visitor
permit per household, upon their request.
   (B)   VISITOR PERMITS are defined as permits used by visitors only.
Residents residing within the city shall not use a visitor permit as permission
to park on city streets.
   (C)   Cost of visitor permit is $5.00 annually and qualifying residents
shall receive one visitor permit per household.
   (D)   Each permit shall have a beginning and ending date clearly defined on
the permit and each permit shall have the resident’s address clearly defined on
the permit.
   (E)   Exception to this rule would be visiting nurses and/or therapist or
medical staff residents may request a special permit for the time needed. Also,
commercial vehicles working at a residence have the authority to use a visitor
permit during the timeframe working.
   (F)   A resident holding a visitor permit shall not give, loan, or sell
their visitor permit to another resident to use as a regular parking permit.
   (G)   Any person found guilty of misusing parking permits shall be fined not
less than $100 and not more than $500.
   (H)   Visitors may park on the streets for a period of not more than two
hours without a parking permit and/or a visitor’s permit.
(Ord. 2168, passed 10-12-21; Ord. 2246, passed 6-9-25)

Section
Article 371: Bicycle Licensing

371.02   Applications

371.07   Dealers' reports required
   
371.08   Liability of owner
   
371.99   Penalty
Statutory reference:
   Authority to restrict use of bicycles on controlled access highways, see W.
V. Code § 17C-7-13
   Bicycle defined, see W. V. Code § 17C-1-8
   Operation of bicycles, see W. V. Code Article 17C-11
ARTICLE 371: BICYCLE LICENSING
§ 371.01 LICENSE AND LICENSE PLATE REQUIRED.
   No person residing in the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street,
sidewalk or public way within the city, unless such bicycle has been licensed
by the city, and unless a license plate issued by the city is firmly attached
to the rear mudguard or frame of the bicycle, in such a position as to be
plainly visible from the rear.
('71 Code, § 371.01)
Penalty, see § 371.99
Statutory reference:
   Authority to license bicycles, see W. V. Code § 17C-2-8(8)
§ 371.02 APPLICATIONS.
   Applications for bicycle licenses and license plates shall be made to the
City Clerk, upon a form provided by the city.
('71 Code, § 371.02)
§ 371.03 INSPECTION OF BICYCLE REQUIRED.
   An applicant for a license for a bicycle shall, before making application to
the City Clerk, personally present his bicycle to the Police Department for
inspection. If the Police Department finds the bicycle in a safe mechanical
condition and the applicant qualified to operate the same, its findings in
these particulars shall be noted in writing upon the application form. The City
Clerk shall refuse to issue licenses for bicycles found by the Police
Department to be in an unsafe mechanical condition or the applicant not
qualified to operate the same.
('71 Code, § 371.03)
§ 371.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The annual license fee for the privilege of riding or propelling a bicycle
on any street, alley or public way within the city shall be $0.50 per year,
which fee shall be paid to the city before the license shall be issued. A
similar fee shall be paid the city for each renewal of such license for the
period commencing July 1 and ending June 30 of each year. The license fee
herein provided for shall not be reduced in the event the application for the
same is made for a fraction of a year.
('71 Code, § 371.04)
§ 371.05 REMOVAL OF LICENSE PLATES.
   The owner of a bicycle shall not remove the license plate from such bicycle
during the period for which it has been issued, except upon a transfer of
ownership of the bicycle, as provided in §
371.06.
('71 Code, § 371.05)
Penalty, see § 371.99
§ 371.06 TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   In the event of transfer of ownership of a bicycle, an application shall be
made by the new owner of the bicycle for the transfer of the license from the
former owner to the new owner of the bicycle. Upon receipt of such application,
the bicycle license shall be so transferred. Upon the sale or other transfer of
a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license plate and shall
either surrender the same to the City Clerk or, upon proper application, but
without payment of an additional license fee, have the license assigned to
another bicycle owner by the applicant.
('71 Code, § 371.06)
§ 371.07 DEALERS' REPORTS REQUIRED.
   Every person engaged in the buying or selling of new or secondhand bicycles
shall make a report to the City Clerk of every bicycle purchased or sold by
such dealer from or to a city resident, giving the name and address of the
person from whom purchased or to whom sold, a bicycle description by name or
make, the frame number and the license plate number, if any, attached to the
bicycle.
('71 Code, § 371.07)
Penalty, see § 371.99
§ 371.08 LIABILITY OF OWNER.
   The owner of any licensed bicycle shall be subject to the penalties
prescribed when his bicycle is operated by another with the owner's consent,
and when such other operator violates any of the provisions of this article or
any traffic regulations applicable to bicycles, as adopted in §
331.01.
('71 Code, § 371.08)
§ 371.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this article or any traffic
regulation applicable to bicycles, as adopted in §
331.01, may be punished by a fine of not more than $10, by removal and
detention of the license plate from such person's bicycle for not more than 120
days or by the impounding of such person's bicycle for not more than 30 days,
or either or all of such penalties. No person under the age of 18 years shall
be imprisoned for violation of the provisions of this article or such traffic
regulations.
('71 Code, § 371.99)

ARTICLE 501: ADMINISTRATION AND LAW ENFORCEMENT
§ 501.01 BRIBING POLICEMEN.
   No person shall give or offer to give any money or other thing of value to
any officer or member of the Police Department as a consideration for the
performance of or the failure to perform any duty of such officer or member of
the Police Department.
('71 Code, § 501.01)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Statutory reference:
   Bribery and corrupt practices generally, see W. V. Code Article 61-5A
   Specific types of bribery, see W. V. Code §§ 3-1-1 et seq., 15-2-17 et seq.,
18-2A-9, 61-10-15 and 61-10-22
§ 501.02 REFUSAL TO AID POLICE OFFICER.
   No person shall, on being required by the Police Chief or other officer,
refuse or neglect to assist him in the execution of his office in a criminal
case, in the preservation of the peace or in the apprehending or securing of
any person for a breach of the peace or in any case of escape or rescue. ('71
Code, § 501.02)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Statutory reference:
   Crimes against public justice, see W. V. Code Article 61-5
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 61-5-14
§ 501.03 OBSTRUCTING POLICE OFFICER.
   (A)   Any person who by threats, menaces, acts, or otherwise, shall forcibly
or illegally hinder, obstruct, or oppose, or attempt to obstruct or oppose, or
shall counsel, advise, or invite others to hinder, obstruct, or oppose any
officer in the state (whether civil or military) in the lawful exercise or
discharge of his official duty, shall, for every such offense, be guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $50 nor
more than $500, and may in the discretion of the court be imprisoned not
exceeding 30 days.
   (B)   If any person intentionally flees from or attempts to flee from any
officer in this state (whether civil or military) who is attempting to make a
lawful arrest of such person, and the person knows or reasonably believes that
the officer is attempting to arrest him or her, he or she is guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $50 nor
more than $500, and may in the discretion of the court be imprisoned for a term
not exceeding 30 days.
('71 Code, § 501.03) (Am. Ord. passed 10-7-96)
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 61-5-17
§ 501.04 REPORTING PERSONS GIVEN EMERGENCY TREATMENT.
   It shall be the duty of every physician practicing in the city to make or
cause to be made a report to the Police Department of any person given
emergency treatment in the city for any personal injuries sustained by such
person by being shot, stabbed, cut, injured in an automobile accident or in any
other manner wounded or injured, giving the name of such injured person and his
address and the place where such treatment is being given. Such report shall be
given immediately after such treatment is rendered by any physician practicing
in the city.
('71 Code, § 501.04)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 501.05 FALSE ALARMS OF FIRE.
   No person shall make, turn in or telephone, or by use of any means or
methods of communication aid or abet in the making or turning in of any alarm
of fire which he knows to be false at the time of making such alarm.
('71 Code, § 501.05)
Penalty, see § 101.99
Cross-reference:
   False alarm fees, see §
704.01
Statutory reference:
   For similar provisions, see W. V. Code § 29-3-21
§ 501.06 RESISTING ARREST.
   No person within the city who is lawfully placed under arrest by a police
officer of the city shall physically resist or impede any police officer from
taking such person into physical custody.
('71 Code, § 501.06) (Ord. 628, passed 11-1-80)
Penalty, see § 101.99
§ 501.07 ASSAULT AND BATTERY ON A POLICE OFFICER.
   (A)   Battery. If any person unlawfully and intentionally makes physical
contact of an insulting or provoking nature with a police officer acting in his
or her official capacity, or unlawfully and intentionally causes physical harm
to a police officer acting in such capacity, such person is guilty of a
misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500
and/or imprisoned for not less than 48 hours and no more than 30 days.
   (B)   Assault. If any person unlawfully attempts to commit a violent injury
to the person of a police officer, or unlawfully commits an act which places a
police officer acting in his or her official capacity in reasonable
apprehension of immediately receiving a violent injury, he or she shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more
than $200 and/or imprisoned for not less than 24 and no more than 30 days.
(Ord. 1190, passed 9-8-97)
§ 501.08 FALSELY REPORTING AN EMERGENCY.
   (A)   A person is guilty of reporting a false emergency incident when,
knowing the information reported, conveyed or circulated is false or baseless,
he or she:
      (1)   Initiates or circulates a false report or warning of or impeding
occurrence of a fire, explosion, crime, catastrophe, accident, illness or other
emergency under circumstances in which it is likely that public alarm or
inconvenience will result or that firefighting apparatus, ambulance apparatus,
one or more rescue vehicles or other emergency apparatus might be summoned; or
      (2)   Reports, by word or action, to any official or quasi-official
agency or organization having the function of dealing with emergencies
involving danger to life or property, an alleged occurrence or impeding
occurrence of a fire, explosion, crime, catastrophe, accident, illness or other
emergency in which it is likely that public alarm or inconvenience will result
or that firefighting apparatus, ambulance apparatus, one or more rescue
vehicles or other emergency apparatus might be summoned, which did not occur,
does not in fact exist; or
      (3)   Reports to a law-enforcement officer or agency the alleged
occurrence of any offense or incident which did not in fact occur or an
allegedly impending occurrence of an offense or incident which is not in fact
about to occur of false information relating to an actual offense or incident
or to the alleged implication of some person therein; or
      (4)   Without just cause, calls or summons by telephone, fire alarm
system or otherwise, any firefighting apparatus, ambulance apparatus, rescue
vehicles or other emergency vehicles.
   (B)   Any person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and,
upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars or
confined in the county jail not more than six months, or both fined and
confined.
(Ord. 1278, passed 4-10-00)
§ 501.09 POLICE DOGS.
   (A)   (1)   Any person who, without justification, willfully and unlawfully
causes physical injury to any trained dog owned, controlled or used by the city
Police Department, or any other law enforcement agency, is guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500, or
confined in the county jail not more than 30 days, or both.
      (2)   Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be
ordered to make restitution to the law enforcement agency owning the animal for
any veterinary bills and replacement costs of any disabled animal.
   (B)   Any person who willfully obstructs, impedes or interferes with the
lawful performance of a trained dog owned, controlled or used by the city
Police Department, or any other law enforcement agency, in a police activity
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined
not more than $500, or confined in the county jail not more than ten days, or
both.
   (C)   Any person who willfully touches or attempts to touch a trained dog
owned, controlled or used by the city Police Department, or any other law
enforcement agency, after being directed not to do so by a law enforcement
officer, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall
be fined not more than $500, or confined in the county jail not more than ten
days, or both.
(Ord. 1536, passed 9-10-07)
§ 501.10 CRIMINAL CONSPIRACY.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for two or more persons to conspire:
      (1)   To commit any offense against the State of West Virginia or the
City of Weirton; or
      (2)   To defraud the State of West Virginia or the City of Weirton, if,
in either case, one of more of such persons does any act to effect the object
of the conspiracy.
   (B)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to supersede, limit,
repeal, or affect the provisions of any other federal, state or municipal law.
It shall not be a defense to any prosecution under this section that the
conduct charged or proven is also a crime under any other provision or
provisions of the West Virginia Code, the common law, or city ordinances.
   (C)   Any person who violates the provisions of this section by conspiring
to commit an offense against the State of West Virginia or City of Weirton
which is a misdemeanor shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction
thereof, shall be punished by confinement in the county jail for not more than
30 days or by a fine of not more than $500, or, in the discretion of the court,
by both such confinement and fine.
(Ord. 1644, passed 6-8-09)
§ 501.11 SEX OFFENDER REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Any person required to register with the West Virginia State Police
Detachment pursuant to W. V. Code Chapter 15, Article 12, §§ 1 through 10 and
either resides in the city limits of the City of Weirton, owns or leases
habitable real property that he or she visits regularly within the city limits
of the City of Weirton, has a place of employment or occupation within the city
limits of the City of Weirton or attends school or a training facility within
the limits of the city shall provide or cooperate in providing, at a minimum,
the following information, in writing, to the Police Department:
      (1)   The full name of the registrant, including any aliases, nicknames,
or other names used by the registrant;
      (2)   The address where the registrant intends to reside or resides, the
address of any habitable real property owned or leased by the registrant that
he or she regularly visits: provided, that a post office box may not be
provided in lieu of a physical residential address, the name and address of the
registrant's employer or place of occupation, the names and addresses of any
anticipated future employers or places of occupation, the name and addresses of
any school or training facility the registrant is attending, and the names and
addresses of any schools or training facilities the registrant expects to
attend;
      (3)   The registrant's Social Security number;
      (4)   A full-face photograph of the registrant;
      (5)   A brief description of the crime or crimes for which the registrant
was convicted;
      (6)   Fingerprints;
      (7)   Information related to any motor vehicle, trailer or motor home
owned or regularly operated by the registrant, including vehicle make, model,
color and license plate number: provided that for the purpose of this section,
the term TRAILER shall mean travel trailer, fold-down camping trailer and house
trailer as those terms are identified in W. V. Code § 17A-1-1;
      (8)   Information relating to any Internet accounts the registrant has
and the screen names, user names or aliases the registrant uses on the
Internet; and
      (9)   Information related to any telephone or electronic paging device
numbers that the registrant has or uses, including, but not limited to,
residential, work and mobile telephone numbers.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall apply both retroactively and
prospectively. This section shall apply to any person who presently is required
to register said information pursuant to W. V. Code Chapter 15, Article 12, §§
1 through 10 inclusive and any person who shall be required to register said
information pursuant to W. V. Code Chapter 15, Article 12, §§ 1 through 10.
   (C)   When any person required to register under this section changes his or
her residence, address, place of employment or occupation, motor vehicle,
trailer or motor home information required by W. V. Code Chapter 15, Article
12, § 2, or school or training facility which he or she is attending or when
any other information required by W. V. Code Chapter 15, Article 12, §§ 1
through 10 changes, he or she shall, within ten business days prior to the date
when the information changes or, if said information is not available to the
registrant within ten business days prior to the changes, then no later than
ten business days after the required information changes, shall inform the
Police Department of the changes in writing.
   (D)   Each time a person has a change in any of the registration information
as required by this section and knowingly fails to register the change or
changes, each failure to register each separate item of information change
shall constitute a separate offense under this section.
   (E)   Any person required to register information pursuant to this section
and knowingly provides materially false information or who refuses to provide
accurate information when so required by the terms of this section, or who
knowingly fails to register or knowingly fails to provide a change in any
required information as required by this section is guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $250 nor more than
$1,000 or confined in jail not more than 30 days, or both.
   (F)   Any person who knows or has reason to know that a person who is
required to register under this section is not complying, or has not complied,
with the requirements of this section and who, with the intent to assist the
sex offender including a law-enforcement agency, including the Police
Department, that is seeking to find the sex offender to question the sex
offender about, or to arrest the sex offender for, his or her noncompliance
with the requirements of this section:
      (1)   Withholds information from the law-enforcement agency, including
the Police Department, about the sex offender's noncompliance with the
requirements of this section and, if known, the whereabouts of the sex
offender;
      (2)   Harbors, or attempts to harbor, or assists another person in
harboring or attempting to harbor, the sex offender;
      (3)   Conceals or attempts to conceal, or assists another person in
concealing or attempting to conceal, the sex offender; or
      (4)   Provides information to the law-enforcement agency, including the
Police Department, regarding the sex offender which the person knows to be
false information is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be fined not less than $250 nor more than $1,000 or confined in jail not
more than 30 days, or both.
(Ord. 1634, passed 4-13-09)
ARTICLE 505: ANIMALS
§ 505.01 NOISY DOGS AND CATS.
   No person shall keep or harbor upon or about his premises any animal of the
dog or cat species, which shall, by barking, howling, squalling, crying or in
any other manner whatsoever, disturb the comfort or quiet of any neighborhood
within the limits of the city.
('71 Code, § 505.01)
Penalty, see § 505.99
Cross-reference:
   Disturbing and unnecessary noises, see §
509.08
Statutory reference:
   Authority to regulate the keeping of animals, see W. V. Code § 8-12-5(26)
   Dogs generally, see W. V. Code Article 19-20
§ 505.02 DOGS AND CATS RUNNING-AT-LARGE.
   (A)   No owner or any person in charge of any dog or cat, whether or not
such dog or cat has attached to it a license tag or whether or not it has been
vaccinated, shall cause or permit such dog or cat to run or be upon a street,
sidewalk or public place within the city or upon any property other than
property owned by or under the control of such person who is the owner of or
has control of such dog or cat unless such dog or cat is accompanied by its
owner or some other person in charge of such dog or cat.
   (B)   Any person or persons violating any provision of this section shall,
upon conviction, be fined for the first offense $75 plus court cost and any
other associated cost, second offense would be a minimum of $175 plus court
cost and any other associated cost with a maximum cost of $500 plus court cost
and any other associated cost, and the impounding of any dog or cat shall not
relieve the owner or person in charge thereof from prosecution for the
violation of this section.
('71 Code, § 505.02) (Ord. 736, passed 5-7-84; Am. Ord. 1692, passed 11-8-10)
§ 505.03 IMPOUNDING OF DOGS.
   Any dog running-at-large within the city limits, whether licensed or not, is
subject to being picked up and impounded at a place designated by the city.
('71 Code, § 505.03) (Ord. 329, passed 3-27-73)
§ 505.04 NOTIFICATION TO OWNER WHEN LICENSED DOG IMPOUNDED.
   (A)   Any dog so impounded shall be kept for a period of seven days, anytime
during which the owner may retrieve the dog by paying a service fee to the
city. Upon receipt of the service fee of $5, the city shall issue a receipt
which when presented to the persons contracted or authorized to pick up and
impound dogs shall serve as a notice that the city's requirements have been
satisfied. The owner of such dog is required to pay all kennel or pound fees to
the owner or manager of the animal holding facility. The owner of any dog so
impounded, if known, is required to pay the service fee regardless whether or
not the dogs impounded are retrieved by the owner. Failure of the owner to pay
the service fee after proper notification that the dog has been impounded,
constitutes a violation of the city dog ordinance and will subject that person
to arrest. The Court Clerk shall send a registered letter to the owner of any
impounded dog notifying that owner of the required service fee. If the service
fee has not been paid within 10 days, an arrest warrant for violation of the
city dog ordinance shall be issued by the Court Clerk.
   (B)   Any dog so impounded and not retrieved after a period of seven days
shall become the property of the pound. Any property so obtained by the pound
shall be disposed of as deemed best and appropriate.
('71 Code, § 505.04) (Ord. 329, passed 3-27-73)
§ 505.05 DISPOSAL OF UNLICENSED DOG.
   When any dog not licensed is impounded, it shall be disposed of as provided
for in W. V. Code Article 19-20.
('71 Code, § 505.05)
§ 505.06 ABANDONING ANIMALS WITHIN THE CITY.
   (A)   No person shall abandon within the city limits any dog or cat or
destroy and leave the carcass of any animal lying exposed; provided, however,
that where any animal is destroyed accidentally, the person causing the
destruction shall immediately notify the Police Department of the time and
location of the accident and shall be absolved from this section.
   (B)   No animal(s) shall reside, be abandoned to, or otherwise be housed in
a dwelling that their owner(s) do no physically occupy; however, in cases
wherein owners can verify the owner’s relocation to another residence, a three-
day (72-hour) grace period from law enforcement’s first observation of animals
in unoccupied residences or structures will be allowed. Continued occupation
thereafter will constitute a violation of this section.
('71 Code, § 505.06) (Ord. 329, passed 3-27-73; Am. Ord. 2189, passed 5-9-22)
Penalty, see § 505.99
§ 505.07 VICIOUS, RABID OR DANGEROUS DOGS.
   (A)   Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to promote the
public health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the City of
Weirton. It is intended to be applicable to "dangerous" and/or "vicious" dogs,
as defined herein, by ensuring responsible handling by their owners through
registration, confinement, and liability insurance.
   (B)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      AMERICAN BULLDOG. Any American Bulldog or old country bulldog, or any
mixed breed of dog which contains, as an element of its breeding, the breed of
American Bulldog or old country bulldog as to be identifiable as partially of
the breed of American Bulldog or old country bulldog. If there is a question of
whether a particular canine fits the definition herein, it will be sufficient
to show identification of a canine as either a pure bred or belonging to a
mixed breed if a member of the American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA)
would identify the canine as such.
      ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER. The Hancock County Animal Control Officer, City
of Weirton Animal Control, and also may apply to city law enforcement personnel
or any person authorized to enforce the laws of the City of Weirton and State
of West Virginia or to investigate and enforce violations relating to animal
control or cruelty.
      AT LARGE. A dog is not under the direct control of the owner, or anywhere
off the premises of the owner.
      CANARY DOG. Any canary dog or Perro de Presa Canario, or any mixed breed
of dog which contains, as an element of its breeding, the breed of canary dog
or Perro de Presa Canario as to be identifiable as partially of the breed
canary dog or Perro de Presa Canario. If there is a question of whether a
particular canine fits the definition herein, it will be sufficient to show
identification of a canine as either a pure bred or belonging to a mixed breed
if a member of the American Veterinary Medical Association (AVMA) would
identify the canine as such.
      DANGEROUS DOG. A dog that, without provocation and subject to division
(C)(2) below, has chased or approached in either a menacing fashion or an
apparent attitude of attack, or has attempted to bite or otherwise endanger any
person, while that dog is off the premises of its owner, keeper, or harborer
and not under the reasonable control of its owner, keeper, harborer, or some
other responsible person, or not physically restrained or confined in a locked
pen which has a top, locked fenced yard or other locked enclosure which has a
top. DANGEROUS DOG means any dog that, because of its aggressive nature,
training or characteristic behavior, presents a risk of serious physical harm
or death to human beings or domestic animals, or would constitute a danger to
human life, physical well-being, or property or other domestic animals if not
kept under the direct control of the owner. This definition shall not apply to
dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties
and does not include a police dog that has chased or approached in either a
menacing fashion or an apparent attitude of attack, or has attempted to bite or
otherwise endanger, any person while the police dog is being used to assist one
or more law enforcement officers in the performance of their official duties.
DANGEROUS DOG includes but is not restricted by or limited to any dog that
according to the records of either any city, any county, any state, or any law
enforcement agency:
         (a)   Has, when provoked, bitten, attacked, endangered, or inflicted
injury on a human being on public or private property, or when unprovoked, has
chased or approached a person upon the street, sidewalks, or any public grounds
in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack, provided that such
actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and
dutifully investigated by any of the above referenced authorities; or
         (b)   Has severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the
owner's property; or
         (c)   Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dog
fighting, or is a dog trained for dog fighting; or
         (d)   Has previously been declared a dangerous dog by another
municipality, any county or any state.
      DIRECT CONTROL. Immediate, continuous physical control of a dog such as
by means of a leash, cord, secure fence, or chain of such strength to restrain
the dog and controlled by a person capable of restraining the dog, or safe and
secure restraint within a vehicle. If the controlling person is at all times
fully and clearly within unobstructed sight and hearing of the dog, voice
control shall be considered direct control when the dog is actually
participating in training or in an official showing, obedience, or field event.
DIRECT CONTROL shall not be required of dogs actually participating in a legal
sport in an authorized area or to government police dogs.
      MENACING FASHION. A dog that would cause any person being chased or
approached to reasonably believe that the dog will cause physical injury to
that person.
      MUZZLE. A leather, wire or device that, when fitted over an animal's
snout, prevents biting and eating.
      OWNER. Any person owning, keeping, possessing, harboring, maintaining, or
having the care, custody or control of an animal.
      PIT BULL TERRIER. Any Staffordshire bull terrier, American pit bull
terrier, or American Staffordshire terrier breed or dog, or any mixed breed of
dog which contains, as an element of its breeding, the breed of Staffordshire
bull terrier, American pit bull terrier, or American Staffordshire Terrier, as
to be identifiable as partially of the breed of Staffordshire bull terrier or
American Staffordshire terrier. If there is a question of whether a particular
canine fits the definition herein; it will be sufficient to show identification
